<article id="post-21" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Sounds of the Music Department</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>A small portion of the great variety of music studied, created, and performed in the Department of Music by students and faculty is sampled on this page. The sounds of Italian opera, Caribbean popular music, jazz, and Baroque music often mingle in the corridor of Morrison Hall. Each semester in Hertz Hall new works by faculty, graduate, and undergraduate composers are performed, department ensembles play noon and evening concerts of European orchestral, choral, and chamber works, as well as chamber music, improvisation in a variety of styles, gospel, and presentations of music and dance from West Africa and Indonesia. Frequent concerts of new music are also held at <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/about/facilities/cnmat.php">CNMAT</a>.</p>
<p>Unless otherwise noted, all sound clips are 30-40 sec excerpts in mp3 format.</p>
<h2>Composers</h2>
<h3><em>Outside Music</em> by Edmund Campion</h3>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/Campion-OutsideMusic.mp3">Outside Music (307kb)</a></p>
<p>San Francisco Contemporary Music Players; David Milnes, Conductor</p>
<h3><em>Timeless Pulse</em> &#8211; Live at CNMAT 2002</h3>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/Wessel-timlesspulse.mp3">Timeless Pulse (551kb)</a></p>
<p>David Wessel, electronics<br />
Pauline Oliveros, Accordion<br />
George Marsh, Percussion<br />
Jennifer Wilsey, Percussion</p>
<h3><em>Nature Is</em> by Cindy Cox</h3>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/Cox_NatureIs.mp3">Nature Is, 5th Movement (481kb)</a></p>
<p>Played by the Continental Trombone Quartet</p>
<h3><em>Song of Songs</em> by Jorge Liderman</h3>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/Liderman_Song.mp3">Song of_Songs (809kb)</a></p>
<p>Funded in part by a UC President&#8217;s Fellowship Grant and the UC Berkeley Consortium for the Arts.</p>
<p>Premiered by Elissa Johnston, Charles Blandy, the Chamber Chorus of the University of California, Berkeley, and the San Francisco Contemporary Music Players<br />
David Milnes, conductor<br />
March 2002, Cal Performances, Berkeley<br />
Soprano, tenor, female chorus, and chamber orchestra:<br />
1(pic)-1-2-0; 2-1-0-0; 2 perc; 2 pf; 1-2-0-1</p>
<h3>&#8220;interaction&#8221; by Mei-Fang Lin</h3>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/MeiFangLin_interaction-excerpt.mp3">&#8220;interaction&#8221; (selection, 768kb)</a></p>
<p>Performed by Mei-Fang Lin</p>
<h3><em>brainFire and bugLight</em> by Trio M / Myra Melford</h3>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/Melford_brainfire.mp3">brainFire and bugLight (566kb)</a></p>
<p>From the recent Trio M album <a href="http://www.cryptogramophone.com/index.php?module=Crypto&amp;func=album&amp;id=134">Big Picture</a></p>
<p>Myra Melford, piano, Mark Dresser, bass, Matt Wilson, drums</p>
<h3><em>On a Sufficient Condition for the Existence of Most Specific Hypothesis</em> by Ken Ueno</h3>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/OSCMSH_online_excertp.mp3">On a Sufficient Condition for the Existence of Most Specific Hypothesis (550kb)</a></p>
<p>concerto for overtone singer &amp; orchestra</p>
<p>Boston Modern Orchestra Project, Gil Rose, conductor, Ken Ueno, vocal soloist.<br />
<a href="http://www.kenueno.com/performancenotes.html#OSC_MSH">Program notes</a><br />
<a href="http://www.kenueno.com/f/mp3/OSCMSH.mp3">Full audio file</a></p>
<h2>Ensembles</h2>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/african_kpalango.mp3">Kpalango</a>, performed by <a title="African Music Ensemble" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/african-music-ensemble/">African Music and Dance Ensemble</a></p>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/bccp_rugucera.mp3">&#8220;Revuelta, Revolución, Rebelión (después de Octavio Paz)&#8221;</a> by graduate student composer Amadeus Rugucera  at the <a title="Berkeley New Music Project (BNMP) featuring the Eco Ensemble" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/berkeley-new-music-project-bnmp-featuring-the-eco-ensemble/">Berkeley New Music Project</a> performance in Hertz Hall, November 24, 2008.<br />
Performed by Berkeley Contemporary Chamber Players: Stacey Pelinka, flute; Darcy Rindt, viola</p>
<p>Excerpt from a 2008 performance in Hertz Hall, <a title="Indonesian (Javanese) Gamelan" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/indonesian-javanese-gamelan/">Javanese Gamelan Ensemble</a></p>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/jcime_odwalla1.mp3">“Theme for Odwalla”</a> by Roscoe Mitchell performed by the <a title="Jazz &amp; Contemporary Improvised Music Ensemble (JCIME)" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/jazz-contemporary-improvised-music-ensemble-jcime/">Jazz &amp; Contemporary Improvised Music Ensemble</a> , noon concert , Hertz Hall, April 2007</p>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/chamber_thowsoraluna.mp3">Cantico Movt. 3 “Sora luna”</a> by John Thow performed by the <a title="University Chamber Chorus" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-chamber-chorus/">University Chamber Chorus</a> in Hertz Hall, 2000</p>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/chorus_matthauspassion.mp3">Matthaus-Passion, Movt. 1</a> exerpt with baroque orchestra performed by the <a title="University Chorus" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-chorus/">University Chorus</a>, recorded live, Hertz Hall, Spring 2006</p>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/gospel_youvebeengoodtome.mp3">“You’ve Been Good to Me”</a> performed by the <a title="University Gospel Chorus" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-gospel-chorus/">University Gospel Chorus</a> on February 24, 2008 in Hertz Hall</p>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/USO-Fall2006_12_08_Bates.mp3">“Rusty Air in Carolina” for orchestra &amp; electronica (2006; 1.25 mb)</a> by Mason Bates (PhD Composition 2008) performed by the <a title="UC Berkeley Symphony Orchestra" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/uc-berkeley-symphony-orchestra/">University Symphony Orchestra</a> in Hertz Hall, Fall 2006</p>
<p>Symphony No 5 in C# minor (1901-04; 1.4 mb) by Gustav Mahler performed by the <a title="UC Berkeley Symphony Orchestra" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/uc-berkeley-symphony-orchestra/">University Symphony Orchestra</a> in Hertz Hall, May 2009</p>
<p><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/wind_track1.mp3">“Foster’s America”</a> by David Gilligham, performed by the <a title="University Wind Ensemble" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-wind-ensemble/">University Wind Ensemble</a> in Hertz Hall in October 2006.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-21 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

</ul>
</li>
<li id="menu-item-4690" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4690"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/about-us/giving-to-music/">Giving to Music</a></li>
</ul></div>			</nav><!-- #access -->
			
	</header><!-- #site-header -->
	
	<div id="main" class="group">
			<div class="content wideness" role="main">
				<div class="page">
								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">
		<form role="search" method="get" id="searchform" class="searchform" action="http://music.berkeley.edu/">
				<div>
					<label class="screen-reader-text" for="s">Search for:</label>
					<input type="text" value="" name="s" id="s" />
					<input type="submit" id="searchsubmit" value="Search" />
				</div>
			</form>						<h2 class="widgettitle">Academics</h2>
<div class="menu-academics-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-academics-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-4696" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4696"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/">Undergraduate Program</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4697" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4697"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/graduate-studies/">Graduate Studies</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4698" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4698"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/concurrent-enrollment/">Concurrent Enrollment</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4699" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4699"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/graduation/">Graduation</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4700" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4700"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/department-of-music-prizes/">Department of Music Prizes</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-5024" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5024"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/recent-dissertations/">Recent Dissertations</a></li>
</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->

						
							
<article id="post-41" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Academic Programs</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<div id="wrapper">
<div id="content">
<p><img class="wp-image-967 size-medium alignright" src="http://dev-department-of-music.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/academics-120x300.jpg" alt="" width="120" height="300" srcset="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/academics-120x300.jpg 120w, http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/academics.jpg 240w" sizes="(max-width: 120px) 100vw, 120px" />The Music Department offers <a title="Undergraduate Degree Program" href="/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/">undergraduate majors and minors</a> in music, and <a title="Graduate Studies" href="/academic-programs/graduate-studies/">graduate M.A./Ph.D. and Ph.D. degrees</a> in music composition, ethnomusicology, and music history and literature.</p>
<p>At the undergraduate level we offer pre-professional training for those seeking a career in some sphere of music. For those with other career goals but who understand the part that music can play in the quality of our lives, we offer substantive grounding and a lasting source of enrichment. Specialized studies at the M.A-Ph.D. level focus on scholarship (the <a title="Graduate Studies in Music History and Literature" href="/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-music-history-and-literature/">history and literature of Western music</a> and <a title="Graduate Studies in Ethnomusicology" href="/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-ethnomusicology/">ethnomusicology</a>) and <a title="Graduate Studies in Music Composition" href="/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-music-composition/">composition</a>.</p>
<p>We are a department (not a School of Music) within the College of Letters and Science, with an internationally-respected faculty who believe that excellence in teaching flows from excellence in scholarly and creative work. If there is one word that describes our pedagogical philosophy, it is &#8220;integration&#8221;: integration in the curriculum of all the spheres of music study that we teach, so that all our undergraduate students acquire musical competence and experience historical and cultural studies, music theory, composition and improvisation, and of course performance.</p>
</div>
</div>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-41 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">

<li id="menu-item-4692" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-4692"><a href="http://www.berkeley.edu/index.html">UC Berkeley</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4693" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-4693"><a href="http://ls.berkeley.edu/">College of Letters &#038; Science</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4694" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4694"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/about-us/contact-music/">Contact Music</a></li>
</ul></div>				</div>

<article id="post-53" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Academic Calendar</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>For information on University-wide dates (such as Tele-BEARS Phases, add/drop deadlines, etc.) see the <a href="http://registrar.berkeley.edu/current_students/registration_enrollment/stucal.html">Berkeley Academic Calendar</a>.</p>

<article id="post-51" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Concurrent Enrollment</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<div id="wrapper">
<div id="content">
<p>Not a student? You can still take some classes in the department for credit through concurrent enrollment. (Enrollment in some classes is limited to registered students). For more information see <a href="http://extension.berkeley.edu/info/ConcurrentOverview.html">UC Berkeley Extension’s website</a>.</p>
</div>
</div>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-51 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">
			
			<div class="footer-nav">
				<div class="menu-footer-menu-container"><ul id="menu-footer-menu" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-4691" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-home menu-item-4691"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/">Welcome</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4692" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-4692"><a href="http://www.berkeley.edu/index.html">UC Berkeley</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4693" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-4693"><a href="http://ls.berkeley.edu/">College of Letters &#038; Science</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4694" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4694"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/about-us/contact-music/">Contact Music</a></li>

<article id="post-47" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Department of Music Prizes</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><strong>The Alfred Hertz Memorial Traveling Scholarship </strong><br />
The Alfred Hertz Memorial Traveling Scholarship is awarded to persons who have manifested unusual talent in music and who show a bona fide intention to devote their lives to music.  It was the donor’s intention to enable recipients to study either in the United States or elsewhere, and he hoped, through the scholarships, to help “find and develop true genius in the art of music.” The amount of the stipend and the number of scholarships awarded each year depends on the overall quality of a given year’s applicants and the qualifications and needs of the individual recipient. Anyone who has ever been affiliated with the University of California, Berkeley is eligible to apply, including current and former students.</p>
<p><strong><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1tkWly-Xl0vOwtGce_RGLQ0tRvUoquoQ-v2uuE3_hUU8/edit?ts=59c14378">Hertz Traveling Scholarship APPLICATION</a></strong></p>
<p><b>The Nicholas C. Christofilos, Jr. Memorial Prize in Music</b><br />
The prize is awarded annually to a graduate student in music who combines qualities of outstanding intellectual accomplishment with concern and support for his or her fellow students.</p>
<p><b>The Nicola de Lorenzo Prize in Composition</b><br />
A first and second prize is awarded annually to qualified students who submit the best-completed musical compositions.</p>
<p><strong>The Musical Theater Prize</strong><br />
This prize is awarded annually to support an original student-written, produced, and performed piece of musical theater (or opera) to be performed in the Department of Music at the end of each Spring semester.</p>
<p><b>Eisner Prizes in the Creative Arts</b><br />
Prizes are awarded annually to undergraduates or graduates for creative achievement in the following fields: English, drama, music, the visual arts, and environmental design. The prizes in music are awarded for outstanding achievement in instrumental or vocal performance or in musical composition.</p>
<p><b>Albert I. Elkus Memorial Prize</b><br />
The prize is awarded annually to four or five outstanding students in Music 27: Introduction to Music, a lecture course, which enrolls approximately 400 non-music majors each semester.</p>
<p><b>George Ladd Prix de Paris</b><br />
The prize is awarded every year to a graduate student in music at the University of California, Berkeley who has attained the highest excellence in his or her studies in harmony and composition. The purpose of the prize is to enable the recipient to study musical composition for one year in Paris, France.</p>
<p><b>The David and Diana Menn Memorial Prize in the Performing Arts</b><br />
Two prizes are awarded annually for outstanding creative talent in the performing arts. One recipient is selected from the students enrolled in the Department of Dramatic Art and the other from the Department of Music.</p>
<p><b>Milton G. Witzel Memorial Prize in Stringed Instrument Performance</b><br />
The prize is awarded annually to an undergraduate or graduate student in the Department of Music for continuing creative achievement in performance on a stringed instrument or to a student composer for work for stringed instruments.</p>
<p><b>The Matthew William Fisher Memorial Award in Music (Departmental Citation)</b><br />
The prize is awarded annually to a graduating senior for all-around excellence and distinction in Music. The prize is publicly acknowledged each spring at commencement. A brief letter is sent to the prize recipient that explains why this award is given in honor of Matthew Fisher.</p>
<p><b>Mary Nunes Souza Music Awards</b><br />
Awards are granted on a competitive basis for special projects designed to supplement the student&#8217;s musical training.</p>
<p><b>Bernece B. Lyon Memorial Prize</b><br />
Awards are granted on a competitive basis for students who propose a worthy project in music performance.</p>
<p><b>Austin F. Williams Prize in Piano Performance</b><br />
Awards are granted in recognition of strong achievement in piano performance.</p>
<h2>Deadlines/Juries</h2>

			</form>						<h2 class="widgettitle">Academics</h2>
<div class="menu-graduate-sidebar-container"><ul id="menu-graduate-sidebar" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-5026" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5026"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/graduate-studies/application-procedures/">Application Procedures</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-5038" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-5038"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/grad_handbook-1.pdf">Grad Handbook</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-5027" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5027"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/graduate-studies/careers/">Careers</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-5033" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5033"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-music-history-and-literature/">Graduate Studies in Music History and Literature</a></li>
</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->

						
							
<article id="post-55" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Studies</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Department of Music at Berkeley is one of the oldest and most prominent in the country, bringing together a renowned group of composers, scholars, and performers. The graduate program is ranked among the top in the nation. The department offers the M.A./Ph.D. and the Ph.D. degrees (for those who have previously completed a Master&#8217;s degree) in composition and scholarship, the latter with options in the history and literature of Western music and in ethnomusicology. The Music Department does not offer the terminal M.A. degree. The program provides graduate students with a solid mastery of their discipline while cultivating a sense of intellectual and creative independence. Students are free to explore related fields of study both within the music program itself and in the larger university. Graduates of the Berkeley Music Department play prominent roles in distinguished musical institutions across the nation and abroad.</p>
<p>Students are supported by fellowships and teaching opportunities. A typical funding package consists of tuition plus a stipend guaranteed for five years (M.A./Ph.D.) or four years (Ph.D.). Additional support for summers and research travel is available by application.</p>
<h2>Areas of specialization</h2>
<h3>Composition</h3>
<p>Students in <a title="Graduate Studies in Music Composition" href="/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-music-composition/">composition</a>  are encouraged to create music that is personal both in style and content while building a firm technical foundation. Composition is taught through seminars and independent studies by all composers on the faculty. Opportunities exist for public performances of student compositions, including chamber, vocal, and orchestral works. Facilities are available for work in electronic and computer music.  For more information, view the <a href="/wp-content/uploads/grad_handbook.pdf">Graduate Student Handbook</a>.</p>
<h3>Ethnomusicology</h3>
<p>Students in <a title="Graduate Studies in Ethnomusicology" href="/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-ethnomusicology/">ethnomusicology</a> prepare for ethnographic research, through the study of cultural theory and methodology from various disciplines. Each student&#8217;s program is individually designed in consultation with an advisor, including opportunities for drawing on Berkeley&#8217;s considerable resources in related disciplines and area studies. For more information, view the <a href="/wp-content/uploads/grad_handbook.pdf">Graduate Student Handbook</a>.</p>
<h3>History and Literature</h3>
<p>Students in the <a href="/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-music-history-and-literature/">history and literature</a> program gain skills for historical research while developing a sense of critical inquiry and intellectual independence. The M.A. program introduces students to musicological methods and techniques and at the same time seeks to broaden their horizons through a variety of courses, including analysis and ethnomusicology. The Ph.D. involves more detailed work in research seminars and special studies. Dissertation topics at Berkeley have run the gamut of scholarly approaches and subjects, from source studies to theoretical or critical works, and from early medieval chant to the music of the present day. For more information, view the <a href="/wp-content/uploads/grad_handbook.pdf">Graduate Student Handbook</a>.</p>
<h2>The Master of Arts Degree</h2>
<p>The period of study in all areas of specialization is from three to (more typically) four semesters ending with the M.A. comprehensive examination. The general course requirement for the M.A. is 24 units, at least 12 of which must be in the graduate series in music.</p>
<h2>The Doctor of Philosophy Degree</h2>
<p>Since the Ph.D. degree is awarded for original, creative achievement, not for the mere completion of a course of study, course and unit requirements are not rigidly prescribed. There is an academic residence requirement of two years. The amount of time needed to complete the Ph.D. varies considerably from one student to another, but students are encouraged to proceed as fast as they can and as the nature of their doctoral project allows. It is expected that the typical student (having obtained an M.A. degree) will have pursued sufficient course work, fulfilled all the supplementary requirements, and taken the qualifying examination, advanced to candidacy, and completed a prospectus for the doctoral project by the end of two years.  After this time the only requirement is that the student satisfactorily complete the doctoral project.</p>
<h3>Careers</h3>
<p><span style="line-height: 1.5;">The traditional career for Ph.D.s in music has been university and college teaching. There are also other professional activities for which a Ph.D. in music is desirable, such as editing, criticism, arts management, music technology, and professional composing.</span></p>
<p>Members of the faculty provide advice on career planning, dossiers, and interviews, as well as recommendations for job candidacies. Berkeley Ph.D.s are likely to compete successfully for positions at leading institutions. Competition, however, is keen and advisors work closely with students to help them plan a course of study that reflects the realities of the job market.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-55 -->

										</div>

	</div><!-- #main -->

<div id="wrapper" class="hfeed">
	
<header id="site-header" class="academics wideness" role="banner">
	 <h1><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu">  Application Procedures</a></h1>

<article id="post-57" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Application Procedures</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h4></h4>
<hr />
<h4>The online application for all graduate programs can be found here: <a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/index.shtml">Application for Graduate Admission and Fellowships</a>. Please submit the application and all supporting materials by December 1st (9:00p.m., P.S.T.) in order to be considered for admission for Fall 2018. No changes can be made to the application after submission.</h4>
<div>
<hr />
<p>Please begin an application to view all of the requirements, including a Statement of Purpose, Personal History Statement, Transcripts, Test Scores, Examples of Scholarship, and Letters of Recommendation.</p>
<p>The Department of Music offers a combined M.A./Ph.D. program and a Ph.D. program (for students who already possess an M.A. in Music with an appropriate emphasis), with specialties in composition, history and literature of Western music, and ethnomusicology. A terminal M.A. degree is not offered. The most appropriate preparation for the graduate program is a B.A. in Music. Applications are considered once a year for admission for the Fall Semester only. Students will be notified of the admission decisions by e-mail no later than March 1st.</p>
</div>
<p>An audition or a formal interview is not required. Applicants who would like to visit the department should contact faculty members in their fields of interest directly. Applicants who are offered admission will be invited to visit the department in February before deciding whether to accept the offer.</p>
<h4>Exam Scores</h4>
<ol>
<li>Official GRE Scores up to five years old should be sent to University Code 4833. Exam scores must be received by December 1st. Note that there is no minimum score requirement.</li>
<li>TOEFL: All applicants from countries in which the official language is not English are required to submit official evidence of English language proficiency by taking the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) in addition to the GRE. For additional information concerning TOEFL, see the <a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/admissions/requirements/#evidence-of-english-language-proficiency">Graduate Division&#8217;s requirements</a>. UC Berkeley&#8217;s code for TOEFL scores is 4833. TOEFL scores must be received by December 1st.</li>
</ol>
<p>If you have any questions, contact our Graduate Student Services Advisor at <a  href="javascript:smae_decode('bXVzaWNncmFkYWR2aXNpbmdAYmVya2VsZXkuZWR1');" >&#109;&#117;&#115;&#105;&#099;&#103;&#114;&#097;&#100;&#097;&#100;&#118;&#105;&#115;&#111;&#114;&#064;&#098;&#101;&#114;&#107;&#101;&#108;&#101;&#121;&#046;&#101;&#100;&#117;</a>.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-57 -->

<article id="post-77" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Careers</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The traditional career for Ph.D.s in music has been university and college teaching. There are also other professional activities for which an M.A. or Ph.D. in music is required or desirable, such as editing, criticism, arts management, music technology, and professional composing.</p>
<p>Members of the faculty provide advice on career planning, dossiers, interviews, etc., as well as recommendations for job candidacies. Berkeley Ph.D.s are likely to compete successfully for positions at leading institutions. Competition, however, is keen and advisers work closely with students to help them plan a course of study that reflects the realities of the job market.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-77 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-73" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Student Instructors</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The department has as one of its principal goals the preparation of teachers for colleges and universities. Every effort is made to ensure that graduates have the knowledge, imagination, and musical and pedagogical skills to enable them to inform and inspire others.</p>
<p>An unusual feature of the program, and a major advantage for students at Berkeley, is the number and variety of courses in which they are given employment and in which they teach under faculty supervision. Teaching experience of this kind is both a philosophical and practical aim of the program and a means of student support. The department employs graduate students (normally after their first year of study) as graduate student instructors in courses in European music history and appreciation, American music cultures, ear training, harmony, computer music, chorus, and orchestra.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-73 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

<li id="menu-item-4692" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-4692"><a href="http://www.berkeley.edu/index.html">UC Berkeley</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4693" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-4693"><a href="http://ls.berkeley.edu/">College of Letters &#038; Science</a></li>

<article id="post-63" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Studies in Ethnomusicology</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The approaches taken to the field of ethnomusicology differ widely. Here at Berkeley we try to achieve a balance &#8212; between theory and practice of music on the one hand, and between theory and methodology of the field of ethnomusicology and a student&#8217;s research specialization on the other. Established in 1975-1976, we are one of the oldest ethnomusicology programs in the United States and are situated in a distinguished music department in the College of Letters and Science. We admit a small number of students, but hope for successful completion by all.</p>
<p>At UC Berkeley, graduate degrees with a primary specialization in ethnomusicology are offered only through the Department of Music. However, it is possible to take &#8220;a field&#8221; in ethnomusicology as part of the graduate program in anthropology, and ethnomusicology faculty work with students in a number of other degree programs.</p>
<p>Specialization in ethnomusicology begins at the M.A. level. If a prospective student has already achieved an M.A. degree in a specialization with substantially different course work, ethnomusicology study at Berkeley will lead first to an additional M.A. degree, then on to the Ph.D. program. Students with M.A. degrees in ethnomusicology from another institution are also welcome to apply. Each student&#8217;s degree program is individually designed in consultation with the advisor. That program consists of courses in our Department, and also courses in supporting disciplines and area studies.</p>
<p>Ethnomusicologists on the faculty of the Department of Music are Benjamin Brinner, Jocelyne Guilbault, and Tamara Roberts. The Central Javanese Gamelan is directed by Midiyanto, Doniel Mark Wilson conducts the Gospel Choir, and C.K. Ladzekpo directs the African Music Ensemble. In addition, artists from the Bay Area offer instruction in various musical traditions, through performance labs for each ethnomusicology lecture course.</p>
<p>In addition to course enrollment, we encourage our students to establish intellectual connections with faculty and with other graduate students on campus through such means as the Townsend Center for the Humanities, area studies centers, such as the Center for African Studies, Center for Eastern European, Slavic, and Eurasian Studies, Center for Middle Eastern Studies, Center for Latin American Studies, Center for South Asian Studies, Center for Southeast Asia Studies, Center for Chinese Studies, Center for Korean Studies, Center for Japanese Studies, and centers and programs with particular foci such as the Center for the Study of Sexual Culture, the Center for International Development, and the Institute for the Study of Social Change.</p>
<p>Beyond the campus, the San Francisco-Oakland Bay area is particularly rich in performances and exhibitions of the world&#8217;s cultures. The Bay Area&#8217;s rich musical life and its diverse array of performing organizations reflects a complete spectrum of musical activity, such as the Ali Akbar College of Music, numerous venues for performance of a wide range of musics from around the world including western classical opera, symphonies, and ballets, as well as a panoply of popular music, folk music, and great jazz venues such as Freight and Salvage, La Peña, and Ashkenaz in Berkeley, Kimball&#8217;s in Emeryville, and Yoshi&#8217;s in Oakland.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-63 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});

<article id="post-59" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Studies in Music Composition</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>Our broad program offers depth in developing the creative musician of the future as composers, composer-performers, improvisers, and composers with special emphasis in technology. Our program aims to prepare students for professional lives as professional practicing artists and as academics.</p>
<p>The works of the composition faculty (Franck Bedrossian, Edmund Campion, Cindy Cox, Myra Melford, and Ken Ueno) are heard regularly around the world, and their presence is deeply embedded into the cultural life of the San Francisco Bay area. Our graduate composers have regular opportunities to hear their music performed by the professional Eco Ensemble through the Berkeley New Music Project (BNMP), conducted by David Milnes. In partnership with the Center for New Music and Audio Technologies (CNMAT) directed by Edmund Campion, students may work with innovative computer technologies.</p>
<p>The department sponsors residencies, workshops and readings with world-class ensembles such as the Ensemble Intercontemporain and the Arditti Quartet. Through the Regent&#8217;s Lecture series and the Bloch Lecture series, we invite prominent composers for extended visits. Recent years have seen our students interacting and learning from Pulitzer Prize winning composers such as William Bolcom and Steven Stuckey, as well as international luminaries like Steve Reich, Jonathan Harvey, Philippe Leroux, Magnus Lindberg, Steve Mackey, and John Adams. Our composition faculty produces a weekly colloquium series which further exposes our students to prominent composers visiting the Bay Area. Many students develop strong ties to professional new music groups and go on to have works programmed by ensembles such as the San Francisco Contemporary Music Players, the Oakland Symphony, the Earplay Ensemble, and the Empyrean Ensemble. The composition faculty mentor and support students through help arranging these opportunities, and attend their performances and readings with the goal of guiding the development of their professional careers. The composition faculty also assists graduate composers in fundraising for their creative projects, and graduate students are represented by the student-led <a title="Berkeley New Music Project (BNMP) featuring the Eco Ensemble" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/berkeley-new-music-project-bnmp-featuring-the-eco-ensemble/">Berkeley New Music Project</a> (BNMP).</p>
<p>In their first year of graduate study the students participate in a two-semester composition seminar where their writing is evaluated and critiqued in a supportive environment. After the first year, the students are required to enroll every semester in private lessons. We frequently offer special seminars on topics of interest to particular faculty. The program (from MA through the completion of the PhD) usually requires about five years to complete.</p>
<p>We encourage our students to seek interaction and collaboration on all levels in the university. Students are encouraged to pursue inter-disciplinary studies both inside and outside the department. Many of our distinguished recent graduates have defined themselves by working closely with the ethnomusicology and history sectors of the department or through significant contact with other departments on campus. Composers have collaborated successfully with the Consortium for the Arts, the Townsend Center for the Humanities, the Pacific Film Archive, the Berkeley Art Museum and Cal Performances (Tempo Festival and Edge Festival). Through CNMAT the graduate composers regularly interact and collaborate with students and faculty from the Department of Psychology, Computer Science and Engineering as well as the Department of Theater and Dance.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-59 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">

<li id="menu-item-4692" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-4692"><a href="http://www.berkeley.edu/index.html">UC Berkeley</a></li>

	</header><!-- #site-header -->
	
	<div id="main" class="group">
			<div class="content wideness" role="main">
				<div class="page">
								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">
		<form role="search" method="get" id="searchform" class="searchform" action="http://music.berkeley.edu/">
				<div>
					<label class="screen-reader-text" for="s">Search for:</label>
					<input type="text" value="" name="s" id="s" />
					<input type="submit" id="searchsubmit" value="Search" />
				</div>
			</form>						<h2 class="widgettitle">Academics</h2>

<li id="menu-item-5033" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-menu-item page_item page-item-67 current_page_item menu-item-5033"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-music-history-and-literature/">Graduate Studies in Music History and Literature</a></li>
</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->

						
							
<article id="post-67" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Studies in Music History and Literature</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The study of musicology as it is practiced at Berkeley values critical and sustained engagement with musical works, studied in relation to the historical and social conditions that shaped their genesis and to the meanings ascribed to them by diverse audiences at the time of their creation and since. Graduate students are encouraged to become conversant with related fields such as anthropology, history, literature, cultural studies, and sociology through formal or individual study. Yet the study of music, musicians, listeners, and the mechanisms that create and disseminate music remain at the center of our course of study. We aim for a balance between the study of historical and social factors that shape music (and are shaped by it in turn) and a deep and detailed probing of musical texts. If our approach to teaching music history and to practicing it in our research differs from more general definitions of the field, it is in a tacit belief in music&#8217;s agency on political and social levels, a conviction that music&#8217;s multiple meanings are recoverable through research and attentive listening, and a commitment to the details and texture of the musical work itself, as experienced both in the score and in performance.</p>
<p>Coursework in both the M.A./Ph.D. and the Ph.D. program begin with pro-seminars devoted to research methods, musicological thought, and (in the second year) ethnomusicology. From the outset, though, students are encouraged to enroll in as many research seminars as possible. The topics for these center on topics chosen by the faculty from year to year, reflecting both current research enthusiasms and perceptions of what the current group of students want and need. Thus our graduate students begin significant independent research and writing projects immediately upon their arrival at Berkeley. Guiding them in writing well and thinking independently about research are two values that distinguish Berkeley&#8217;s approach to musicological education at the graduate level. The program is structured at every stage to support and foster individual approaches to musicological work. The M.A. exam is individually designed, beginning from a list of eight topics spanning different historical periods, musical genres, and methodological approaches chosen by the student. The qualifying exam, taken just before a student embarks on writing the dissertation, is intended to establish a strong base for dissertation research and teaching in one&#8217;s area of specialization, and focuses on three broad topics relevant to the dissertation. Lively conversation marks the Berkeley musicology program at all stages, from seminar discussions to question periods after talks by visiting speakers to one-on-one mentoring on the dissertation and professional activities.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-67 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">


		<div id="footer-content">

</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->

						
							
<article id="post-75" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">General Requirements</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>Each of the graduate programs &#8212; <a title="Graduate Studies in Music Composition" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-music-composition/">composition</a>, <a title="Graduate Studies in Ethnomusicology" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-ethnomusicology/">ethnomusicology</a>, and <a title="Graduate Studies in Music History and Literature" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/graduate-studies/graduate-studies-in-music-history-and-literature/">history and literature</a> &#8212; has a set of requirements that are tailored for the particular specialization. Please see the specific sections in the <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/grad_handbook-1.pdf">Graduate Student Handbook</a> for details.</p>
<h2>Fellowship Eligibility</h2>
<p>Enrollment in a minimum of 12 units per semester is required to remain eligible for a fellowship.</p>
<h2>Language Proficiency</h2>
<p>Doctoral students must satisfy a foreign language requirement of reading knowledge of two languages.</p>
<p>Proficiency in a language is usually demonstrated by a written examination consisting of a passage (or passages) totaling a minimum of 300 words, at least partly taken from the literature on music. Proficiency in the second language may be established either by examination or by four semesters of coursework with a grade of B or better. For students who enter at the M.A. level, one language must be completed before the M.A. exam. Students entering at the Ph.D. level must complete both language requirements prior to completion of the Qualifying Exam.</p>
<h2>Graduate Student Instructors</h2>
<p><span style="line-height: 1.5;">The department employs graduate students after their first year of study to be graduate student instructors in a variety of courses in European music history, American music cultures, ear training, harmony, computer music, chorus, and orchestra. </span>Teaching experience and training of this kind are philosophical and practical aims of the program, and a primary means of student support.</p>
<h2>The Ph.D. Qualifying Exam</h2>
<p>The purpose of the Qualifying Examination is to determine that the student is an expert in those areas that have been specified for the examination, and can in all likelihood design and produce an acceptable dissertation.</p>
<p>The Ph.D. Qualifying Exam Committee consists of four faculty members: three from the Department of Music and one outside member who must be a member of the Academic Senate. One of the members of the committee functions as chair. The chair of the committee must be a member of the Academic Senate and cannot be the same as the chair of the student&#8217;s dissertation committee.</p>
<h2>The Doctoral Dissertation</h2>
<p>Each doctoral candidate must be responsible for and prepare a dissertation representing his or her own contribution to original scholarship or creative work. The student&#8217;s project must be approved and guided by a Dissertation Committee comprising three members of the faculty, including the Dissertation Chair and two additional pertinent specialists, one of whom must be from a department other than Music.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-75 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-4199" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Earlier Ph.D. Dissertations</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><a title="Recent Dissertations" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/recent-dissertations/">Back to Recent Dissertations</a></p>
<h2>1989</h2>
<p><strong>Stephen Parkany</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; A. Newcomb, adviser</p>
<p>Kurth&#8217;s Bruckner and the Vocabulary of Symphonic Formal Process in the Late Nineteenth Century</p>
<p><strong>Dorit Tanay</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; R. Crocker, adviser</p>
<p>Music in the Age of Ockham: The Interrelations between Music, Mathematics, and Philosophy in the 14th Century</p>
<p><strong>Evan Ziporyn</strong></p>
<p>Composition; R. Felciano, adviser</p>
<p><em>Walk</em></p>
<h2>1988</h2>
<p><strong>Julie Cumming</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; D. Heartz, adviser</p>
<p>Concord Out of Discord: Occasional Motets of the Early Quattrocento</p>
<p><strong>Thomas Grey</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; A. Newcomb, adviser</p>
<p>Richard Wagner and the Aesthetics of Musical Form in the Mid-19th Century</p>
<p><strong>Randall Packer</strong></p>
<p>Composition; E. Dugger, adviser</p>
<p><em>Gamous</em> Concerto for Percussion Soloist and Chamber Ensemble</p>
<h2>1987</h2>
<p><strong>Pieter Van den Toorn</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; A. Imbrie, adviser</p>
<p>Stravinsky and <em>The Rite of Spring</em></p>
<h2>1986</h2>
<p><strong>Christopher Fulkerson</strong></p>
<p>Composition; O. Wilson, adviser</p>
<p><em>The Recognitions</em> for Orchestra</p>
<h2>1985</h2>
<p><strong>Benjamin Brinner</strong></p>
<p>Ethnomusicology; B.C. Wade, adviser</p>
<p>A Study of Pathetan in Central Javanese Gamelan Music</p>
<p><strong>Scott DeVeaux</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature, O. Wilson, adviser</p>
<p>Jazz in the Late 1930s and early 1940s: The Transition from &#8220;Swing&#8221; to &#8220;Bop&#8221;</p>
<p><strong>Patrick Macy</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; J. Kerman, adviser</p>
<p>Josquin&#8217;s <em>Miserere mei Deus</em>: Context, Structure, and Influence</p>

<p>Composition; A. Imbrie, adviser</p>

<p>Composition; O. Wilson, adviser</p>

Music for Winds under the Revolution and First Empire</p>
<p><strong>Keith Polk</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; D. Heartz, adviser<br />
Flemish Wind Bands in the Late Middle Ages: A Study of Improvisatory Instrumental Practices</p>
<p><strong>Marvin Tartak</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; J. Kerman, adviser<br />
The Comic Operas of Rossini</p>
<h2>1967</h2>
<p>none</p>
<h2>1966</h2>
<p>none</p>
<h2>1965</h2>
<p>none</p>
<h2>1964</h2>
<p><strong>Roland Jackson</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; J. Kerman, adviser<br />
The Keyboard Music of Giovanni Maria Trabaci</p>
<p><strong>P. Sigurd Odegard</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; J. Kerman, adviser<br />
The Variation Sets of Arnold Schoenberg</p>
<h2>1963</h2>
<p>none</p>
<h2>1962</h2>
<p><strong>Donald Hersh</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; J. Kerman, adviser<br />
Verdelot and the Early Madrigal</p>
<h2>1961</h2>
<p><strong>Martin Chusid</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; E. Sparks, adviser<br />
The Chamber Music of Schubert</p>
<h2>1960</h2>
<p><strong>Martin Picker</strong></p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; Lewinsky, adviser</p>
<p>The Chanson Albums of Marguerite of Austria: Manuscripts 228 and 11239 of the Bibliotheque Royale de Belgioue, Bruxelles</p>
<h2>1959</h2>
<p><strong>Sydney Charles</strong></p>
<p>History and Literature</p>
<p>The Music of the Pepys Ms 1236</p>
<h2>1958</h2>

The Cyclic Masses of Trent Codex 89</p>
<h2>1957</h2>
<p>none</p>
<h2>1956</h2>

<p>History &amp; Literature; Bukofzer, adviser</p>

<h2>1955</h2>
<p>none</p>

<h2>1953</h2>
<p><strong>Vincent Duckles</strong></p>

<h2>1952</h2>

<h2>1951</h2>

<h2>1949</h2>
<p>none</p>
<h2>1948</h2>
<p><strong>Louis P. Nash</strong></p>
<p>Stylistic Aspects of the Church music of William Byrd (Master&#8217;s thesis)</p>
<p><strong>Robert M. Morton</strong></p>
<p>Duo Sonata for Violin and Piano (Master&#8217;s thesis)</p>
<p><strong>L. Jane Hohfeld</strong></p>

<h2>1947</h2>
<p><strong>Leonard Gilbert Ratner</strong>*</p>
<p>History &amp; Literature; M. Bukofzer, adviser</p>

<p>*1947: first History and Literature dissertation filed</p>
<h2>1947</h2>
<p><strong>Harrison Olaf Hayes</strong></p>
<p>The function and Evolution of the Operatic Overture (MA, D. Boyden, adviser)</p>
<p><strong>Andrew Welch Imbrie</strong></p>

<h2>1946</h2>
<p><strong>Arthur John Bryon</strong></p>
<p>String Quartet (Composition: A. Elkus, adviser)</p>
<p><strong>Haig Kafafian</strong></p>
<p>A Study of Certain Triade and Their Inversions in the Bach Chorales</p>
<p><strong>Sister Therese Cecile Murphy</strong></p>
<p>Dissonance Treatment in the Works of Lassus (M. Bukofzer, adviser)</p>
<p><strong>Ralph Schellehous Smith</strong></p>
<p>The Harmonic System of Paul Hindemith and its Application to Somo Harmonic Devices of Twentieth Century Composers (M. Bukofzer, adviser)</p>
<h2>1945</h2>
<p><strong>Mary Louise Clement</strong></p>
<p>The Approach to the Cadence in High Renaissance Music (M. Bukofzer, adviser)</p>
<p><strong>Eugene Carol Meltzer </strong></p>
<p>A Stylistic Analysis of the Songs of Robert Schumann (D. Boyden, adviser)</p>
<p><strong>Grace Wares Moore</strong></p>
<p>Instrumental Idiom in the Seventeenth Century (D. Boyden, adviser)</p>
<p><strong>Roschelle Zella Paul</strong></p>
<p>Song Tradition of the University of California at Berkeley</p>
<p><strong>Water Tullis</strong></p>
<p>Variations and Fugue on an Original Theme for Piano (Composition; A. Elkus, adviser)</p>
<h2>1943</h2>
<p><strong>Rise Resnick</strong></p>
<p>Studies of Humor in Instrumental Music of the late 18th and 19th Centuries</p>
<h2>1942</h2>
<p><strong>Warren Miles Anderson</strong></p>
<p>Sonata for Violin and Piano.</p>
<h2>1941</h2>
<p><strong>Winifred Bliss Howe</strong></p>
<p>A Comparative Study of Selected Ballad Tune Variants of the Present Day</p>
<p><strong>Kathleen Mavourneen Hughes</strong></p>
<p>The Decline of the Viola da Gamba and the Rise of the Violoncello</p>
<p><strong>Louis Ferdinand Schliemann</strong></p>
<p>A Study of Stylistic Changes in the works of Dufay</p>
<p><strong>Austin Henry Thomson</strong></p>
<p>Modifications of the &#8220;Cantus Firmus&#8221; Technique Evidenced in &#8220;Introits&#8221; by Heinrich Isaac and Blasius Amon</p>
<h2>1940</h2>
<p><strong>Joan Castledine Habis-Reutinger</strong></p>
<p>The Historical approach to Purcell&#8217;s Chamber Opera &#8220;Dido and Aeneas,&#8221; with special reference to Blow&#8217;s &#8220;Venus and Adonai&#8221;</p>
<p><strong>Margaret Marie Kirchhofer</strong></p>
<p>&#8220;Mister Aesop&#8221; Fables for Baritone and Women&#8217;s Chorus, with piano accompaniment: I. The Fox and the Crow; II. The Milkwoman and Her Pail; III. The Lion and the Mouse; IV. The Hare and the Tortoise; V. The Bald Knight</p>
<p><strong>Elizabeth May</strong></p>
<p>Claude Lejeune and his music</p>
<h2>1939</h2>
<p><strong>Maurice Barryte</strong></p>
<p>The Symphonies of Schumann: Their form and their relation to the Symphonies of Beethoven</p>
<p><strong>Marjorie Jackson</strong></p>
<p>The Evolution of the Oboe and of its use in the Symphony Orchestra, with a section on Reed Making</p>
<p><strong>James Mitchell</strong></p>
<p>Inquiry into the Vertical Significance of the Counterpoint of Duynstable, and into the Extent and Treatment of Organized Tonal Combinations</p>
<p><strong>Leonard Gilbert Ratner</strong></p>
<p>Unusual and Composite Forms in Beethoven&#8217;s Instrumental Works, with Especial Reference to the Persistent Recurrence of Rondo-like form (Master&#8217;s thesis)</p>
<h2>1937</h2>
<p><strong>Mary Elizabeth Johnston</strong></p>
<p>String Quartet (No. 1) (Composition)</p>
<p><strong>Sirvart Vartan Poladian</strong></p>
<p>The Folk Songs of Asia Minor</p>
<p><strong>Dale Edmund Sandifur</strong></p>
<p>&#8220;Suite&#8221; for String Quartet (Composition)</p>
<h2>1936</h2>
<p><strong>Georgie Rees Cason</strong></p>
<p>An Introduction to a study of California Indian Music</p>
<h2>1935</h2>

<h2>1934</h2>
<p><strong>Walter Horace Bundy</strong></p>

<p><strong>Isaac Lloyd Hibberd</strong></p>

<p><strong>Water David Hirschl</strong></p>
<p>The Styles of Victoria and Palestrina: A comparative Study, with special reference to Dissonance Treatment</p>
<h2>1933</h2>
<p><strong>Philip Johan Adolf Sehinhan</strong></p>

<p><strong>Barbara Lee Maede</strong></p>
<p>A Study of the Treatment of the Words in &#8220;Pelleas et Melisande&#8221;</p>
<p><strong>Henry George Mishkin</strong></p>
<p>The Augmented Second: A Study in the Evolution of a Prejudice</p>
<p><strong>Philip Brown Norman</strong></p>
<p>A System of Harmony Based on the Chromatic Scale and Illustrated with Examples from Wagner</p>
<p><strong>Beatrice Ada Colton</strong></p>
<p>Quartet for Piano and Strings (Composition)</p>
<p><strong>William Douglas Denny</strong></p>
<p>Concerto in D for Violin and Orchestra (Composition)</p>
<h2>1932</h2>
<p><strong>Theodore Gorbacheff, </strong></p>
<p>&#8220;The Russian Liturgy,&#8221; For Mixed, Men&#8217;s, and Women&#8217;s choirs, &#8220;A Cappella&#8221; (Composition)</p>

<h2>1931</h2>
<p><strong>Leslie Paul Clausen</strong></p>

<p><strong>Dorothy Gillespie Knowlton</strong></p>

<p><strong>Charles Cook Cushing</strong></p>

<p><strong>Mary Elizabeth Millard </strong></p>

<p><strong>Jay Leon Ruddick</strong></p>

<article id="post-71" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduate Fellowships</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2>Graduate Fellowships</h2>
<p>The Music Department provides a minimum of five years of support to students who enter on the M.A. level and a minimum of four years to those who enter on the Ph.D. level. This support includes tuition, fees, and health insurance. Students are awarded a fellowship in their first year. Support in subsequent years is in the form of a combination of fellowships and appointments as Graduate Student Instructors. In addition, students apply for <a href="http://grad.berkeley.edu/financial/fellowships/">Graduate Division and Extramural Fellowships</a> during their tenure as a graduate student.</p>
<h2>The George Ladd Prix de Paris</h2>
<p>The George Ladd Prix de Paris is awarded to a distinguished graduate student composer in the Music Department. The award supports one year of study in Paris, France. To be considered for the award, students must have completed the M.A. degree and usually will have passed the Qualifying Exams. Awards are made on the basis of faculty nomination. The stipend level is determined by student need.</p>
<p>When applying to our graduate program, we encourage students to investigate and apply for funding that is external to the University of California, Berkeley. The Jacob K. Javits Fellowship Program, Andrew W. Mellon Foundation grants, and Ford Foundation grants of good examples of such a source. For international students, the possibilities for a Fulbright Fellowship might be investigated.</p>
<h2></h2>
<h2>Traveling Hertz Fellowships</h2>
<p>Alfred Hertz Memorial Traveling Scholarships are intended for persons who have unusual talent in music and who show a bona fide intention to devote their lives to music. It was the donor&#8217;s intention to enable recipients of these scholarships to study away from Berkeley either in the United States or elsewhere. Anyone who has been affiliated with the University of California, Berkeley may apply before February 15.</p>
<p><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1tkWly-Xl0vOwtGce_RGLQ0tRvUoquoQ-v2uuE3_hUU8/edit?ts=59c14378">Hertz Fellowship Application</a></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-71 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<header id="site-header" class="academics wideness" role="banner">
	 <h1><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu">  Graduation</a></h1>
			<nav id="main-nav" role="navigation">
				<div class="menu-main-menu-custom-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-main-menu-custom-header-menu" class="sf-menu"><li id="menu-item-4628" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-home menu-item-4628"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/">Home</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4629" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-4629"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/about-us/">About Us</a>
<ul class="sub-menu">
	<li id="menu-item-4632" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4632"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/about-us/history/">History</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-4633" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4633"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/about-us/resources-and-facilities/">Resources and Facilities</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-4634" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4634"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/about-us/sounds-of-the-music-department/">Sounds of the Music Department</a></li>

<article id="post-45" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Graduation</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<div id="wrapper">
<div id="content">
<p><b><img class="wp-image-996 size-medium alignright" src="http://dev-department-of-music.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/commencment08-w-300x199.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="199" srcset="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/commencment08-w-300x199.jpg 300w, http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/commencment08-w.jpg 336w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" />Penultimate Semester Before Graduating Semester</b>:</p>
<p>Students should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Review their academic record for any outstanding requirements; you may wish to run a degree audit report in CalCentral</li>
<li>Complete a degree check with major advisor <a href="/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/advising/">Zoe Xu</a> to ensure that all major requirements will have been met;</li>
<li>Complete a degree check with <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/ls-office-undergraduate-advising">Letters and Science advisors</a> to ensure that all college and university requirements will have been met.</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Graduating Semester:</strong></p>
<p>Follow instructions on the <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/advising/academic-progress/graduation">Letters &amp; Science Advising website about declaring candidacy</a>.</p>
<p>Follow instructions provided by the Undergraduate Advisor via email to register for the spring Music Department Commencement Ceremony.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h3>Commencement:</h3>
<p>The Music Department Commencement Ceremony is held once every year in the spring. Commencement typically takes place in Hertz Hall on the second or third Saturday or Sunday in May beginning at noon with a concert by the Eisner Prize recipients. After conferral of graduate and undergraduate degrees, there will be a reception in the lobby of Hertz Hall. See the <a title="Academic Calendar" href="/academic-programs/academic-calendar/">Academic Calendar</a> for the exact date of Commencement.</p>
<p>The commencement registration period begins on January 31 and ends on the first Monday of April, at noon. Students must register by the deadline in order for their name to appear in the program. Instructions will be provided by the Undergraduate Advisor via email when the registration period begins.</p>
<p>Official graduation is not the same as commencement ceremonies.It is not necessary to place yourself on a degree list in order to participate in that term&#8217;s commencement. If a student plans to complete their degree requirements in a Summer or Fall semester, s/he may &#8220;walk&#8221; in the ceremony in the preceding Spring semester; if a student plans to graduate in a Fall semester, s/he may choose to attend the ceremony held in the preceding Spring semester or the following one. Each student may participate in the department commencement ceremony only once. For each commencement ceremony, eligible participants are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Degree recipients in the current Spring semester</li>
<li>Degree recipients in the Summer semester that immediately follows</li>
<li>Degree recipients in the immediately-preceding Fall semester, who did not participate in the previous year&#8217;s commencement</li>
<li>Degree recipients in the immediately-following Fall semester, but they will not be eligible to participate in the next year&#8217;s commencement</li>
</ul>
<p>Students must register and purchase tickets for the <a href="https://commencement.berkeley.edu/">university commencement</a> separately.</p>
</div>
</div>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-45 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

<article id="post-363" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Juries</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>Students who are funded for 6 lessons or less do not need to perform a jury UNLESS they hope to obtain funding for more than 6 lessons the next semester.</p>
<p>Juries are held at the end of each semester for all students taking 150 whether or not they plan on continuing in 150 the following semester. Before the juries, students and their teachers must complete a form describing their goals and repertoire for the semester. Students need to complete their side of the form first and then give it to their teacher. After completing their side of the form, teachers should return the completed forms to their students in a sealed envelope, signed across the closure.</p>
<p>The sealed envelope must be turned into the Music Department office by the Friday before that semester&#8217;s jury or brought to the jury. Students who fail to return the completed form by the due date will not be permitted to take their jury.</p>
<h2>Jury Guidelines</h2>
<p><b>Vocal Students</b>: Over the course of their studies, we expect that student singers will work on a variety of pieces from the art song, opera, and oratorio repertoire in English, Italian, French and German. For their ten-minute jury, students should be prepared to sing two or three pieces in contrasting styles and in at least two languages. Singers are expected to perform their pieces from memory with full comprehension of the text they are singing.</p>
<p><b>Instrumental (including Keyboard) Students</b>: Over the course of their studies, students should prepare representative pieces spanning all relevant time periods and a variety of styles and genres. Accordingly, for their eight- to ten-minute jury, students should prepare one of the following three options:</p>
<ul>
<li>Two contrasting pieces from contrasting stylistic periods; or</li>
<li>Two contrasting movements or sections from a single large piece; or</li>
<li>A single piece at the discretion of their teacher (on a one-time basis only), in the event that the student has undertaken focused work which demonstrates specific accomplishment (for example, the composition or improvisation of an original cadenza; an etude chosen to address a technical problem, etc.)</li>
</ul>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-363 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->

<article id="post-4198" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Recent Dissertations</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2>2017</h2>
<p><b>Lily Chen</b><br />
Composition; K. Ueno, advisor<br />
A Leaf Falls After, for orchestra</p>
<p><strong>Ian Goldstein</strong><br />
Ethnomusicology; B. Brinner, advisor<br />
Experiencing Musical Connection: Sonic Interventions in Mediterranean Social Memory</p>
<p><b>John Kapusta</b><br />
History and Literature; M.A. Smart, advisor<br />
American Music in the Culture of Self-Actualization: Composition and Performance in the Long 1970s</p>
<p><strong>Ilya Rostovtsev</strong><br />
Composition; E. Campion, advisor<br />
Scenes, For Two-Channel Fixed Media</p>
<h2>2016</h2>
<p><strong>Eleanor Cloutier</strong><br />
History and Literature; M. A. Smart, advisor<br />
Repetitive Novelty: Italian Opera in Paris and London in the 1830s and 1840s</p>
<p><strong>Sivan Eldar</strong><br />
Composition; E. Campion, advisor<br />
Sniper’s Lake: Music for Dance</p>
<p><strong>Ofer Gazit</strong><br />
Ethnomusicology; B. Brinner, advisor<br />
Sounds Like Home: Immigrant Musicians on the New York Jazz Scene</p>
<p><b>Inderjit Kaur</b><br />
Ethnomusicology; B. Wade, advisor<br />
When “Unheard Sound” (Re)Sounds: Affective Listening, Ethical Affects, and Embodied Experience in Sikh Sabad Kirtan</p>
<p><b>Amadeus Regucera</b><br />
Composition; K. Ueno, advisor<br />
OPHELIA. Her heart is a clock</p>
<h2>2015</h2>
<p><b>Leon Chisholm</b><br />
History and Literature; J. Davies, advisor<br />
Keyboard Playing and the Mechanization of Polyphony in Italian Music, Circa 1600</p>
<p><b>Rama Gottfried</b><br />
Composition; , F. Bedrossian, advisor<br />
flint</p>
<p><b>Jessica Herdman</b><br />
History and Literature; J. Davies, advisor<br />
Musical Affective Economies and the Wars of Religion in Lyon</p>
<p><b>Tiffany Ng</b><br />
History and Literature; R. Taruskin, advisor<br />
The Heritage of the Future: Historical Keyboards, Technology, and Modernism</p>
<p><b>Olga Panteleeva</b><br />
History and Literature; R. Taruskin, advisor<br />
Formation of Russian Musicology from Sacchetti to Asafyev, 1885-1931</p>
<p><b>Sumitra Ranganathan</b><br />
Ethnomusicology; B. Wade, advisor<br />
Dwelling in my Voice: Tradition as musical judgment and aesthetic sense in North Indian classical Dhrupad</p>
<p><b>Matthew Schumaker</b><br />
Composition; E. Campion, advisor<br />
As I ride the late night freeways (2014-15) For soprano and orchestra</p>
<p><b>Thatchatham Silsupan</b><br />
Composition; K. Ueno, advisor<br />
&#8230;who can recall the past lives&#8230;, for large ensemble</p>
<p><b>Merav Singer</b><br />
Ethnomusicology; B. Brinner, advisor<br />
Singing as an Israeli Woman: Musical Personae in a Cosmopolitan Society</p>
<p><b>Anicia Timberlake</b><br />
History and Literature; R. Taruskin, advisor<br />
The Politics and Practice of Children&#8217;s Music Education in the German Democratic Republic, 1949-1976</p>
<p><b>Rachana Vajjhala</b><br />
History and Literature; R. Taruskin, advisor<br />
The Politics of Belle Epoque Ballet</p>
<h2>2014</h2>
<p><b>Robert Beahrs</b><br />
Ethnomusicology; B. Brinner, advisor<br />
Post-Soviet Tuvan Throat-Singing (Xoomei) and the Circulation of &#8220;Nomadic&#8221; Sensibility</p>
<p><b>Laura Biggs</b><br />
History and Literature; M. A. Smart, advisor<br />
Musical Materialities in Milan and Liberal Italy at the fine secolo</p>
<p><b>Emily Frey</b><br />
History and Literature; R. Taruskin, advisor<br />
Russian Opera in the Age of Psychological Prose</p>
<p><b>Jose Neglia</b><br />
Ethnomusicology; J. Guilbault, advisor<br />
&#8220;The Sound of Here and Now&#8221;: Cultural Production, Revivalism, and Amateurism in the Tokyo Garage Rock Scene</p>
<p><b>Michael Nicholas</b><br />
Composition; C. Cox, advisor<br />
Concerto for piano and string orchestra</p>
<p><b>Rachel Vandagriff</b><br />
History and Literature; R. Taruskin, advisor<br />
The History and Impact of the Fromm Music Foundation, 1952-1983</p>
<h2>2013</h2>
<p><strong>Yael Braunschweig </strong><br />
History and Literature; R. Taruskin, advisor<br />
Biographical Listening: Intimacy, Madness and the Music of Robert Schumann</p>
<p><strong>Nils Bultmann</strong><br />
Composition; E. Campion, advisor<br />
Six Musical Compositions Integrating Digital Video</p>
<p><strong>Sean Curran</strong><br />
History and Literature; R. Taruskin, advisor<br />
Vernacular Book Production, Vernacular Polyphony, and the Motets of the &#8220;La Clayette&#8221; Manuscript (Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, nouvelles acquisitions françaises 13521)</p>
<p><strong>Robin Estrada</strong><br />
Composition; C. Cox, advisor<br />
Binaleg at Sinulug para sa Orkestra</p>
<p><strong>Matthew Goodheart</strong><br />
Composition; K. Ueno, advisor<br />
for 17 instruments</p>
<p><strong>Jonathan Rhodes Lee</strong><br />
History and Literature; D. Moroney, advisor<br />
Virtue Rewarded: Handel&#8217;s Oratorios and the Culture of Sentiment</p>
<p><strong>Ulrike Petersen</strong><br />
History and Literature; R. Taruskin, advisor<br />
Operetta after the Habsburg Empire</p>
<p><strong>Kendra Salois</strong><br />
Ethnomusicology; J. Guilbault, advisor<br />
The Networked Self: Hip Hop Musicking and Muslim Identities in Neoliberal Morocco</p>
<h2>2012</h2>
<p><strong>Carla Brunet</strong><br />
Ethnomusicology; J. Guilbault, advisor<br />
Performance of Identity in Brazilian Carnival Gender, Music, and Dance<br />
Brazilian Popular Musics and Related Caribean Musical Genres</p>
<p><strong>Daniel Cullen</strong><br />
Composition; F. Bedrossian, advisor<br />
&#8220;Stream&#8221; for violin in three settings</p>
<p><strong>Scott Edwards</strong><br />
History and Literature; K. Van Orden, advisor<br />
Repertory Migration in the Czech Crown Lands, 1570-1630</p>
<p><strong>Miki Kaneda</strong><br />
Ethnomusicology; B.C. Wade, advisor<br />
Unexpected Collectives: Intermedia Art in Postwar Japan</p>
<p><strong>Jason Levis</strong><br />
Composition; C. Cox, advisor<br />
Plum Blossom Warm Gentle Wind Shimmering Stillness, for Bass Trombone and Ensemble</p>
<p><strong>Jimmy Lopez</strong><br />
Composition; E. Campion, advisor<br />
Synesthèsie, for orchestra</p>
<p><strong>Emily Richmond Pollock</strong><br />
History and Literature; M.A. Smart, advisor<br />
Opera after Stunde Null</p>
<p><strong>John Richard Prescott</strong><br />
History and Literature; D. Moroney, advisor<br />
John Stanley, &#8220;A Miracle of Art and Nature&#8221;: The role of disability in the life and career of a blind eighteenth-century musician</p>
<h2>2011</h2>
<p><strong>Rebekah Susannah Ahrendt</strong><br />
History and Literature; K. Van Orden, advisor<br />
A Second Refuge: French Opera and the Huguenot Migration, 1685–1713</p>
<p><strong>Evelyn Ficarra</strong><br />
Composition; E. Campion, advisor<br />
Vagues/Fenêtres, for string trio and electronic sounds</p>
<p><strong>Heather Frasch</strong><br />
Composition; F. Bedrossian, advisor<br />
the silence that reigns&#8230;.</p>
<p><strong>John MacCallum</strong><br />
Composition; E. Campion, advisor<br />
El Árbol de la Noche Triste, for viola and electronics</p>
<p><strong>Adeline Otis Mueller</strong><br />
History and Literature; M.A. Smart, advisor<br />
Zauberkinder: Children and Childhood in Late Eighteenth-Century Singspiel and Lieder</p>
<p><strong>Robert Morito Yamasato</strong><br />
Composition; E. Campion, advisor<br />
Scherzo No. 2</p>
<h2>2010</h2>
<p><strong>Marié Abe</strong><br />
Ethnomusicology; J. Guilbault and B.C. Wade, advisor<br />
Sounding Counter-Geographies: Chindon-ya Resurgence and Japan’s “Multicultural Question”</p>
<p><strong>Rebecca Marina Bodenheimer</strong><br />
Ethnomusicology; J. Guilbault, advisor<br />
Localizing Hybridity: The Politics of Place in Contemporary Cuban Rumba Performance</p>
<p><strong>David Christian Coll</strong><br />

	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

jQuery(document).ready(function($){
    $(".gallery img").each(function(){
        var alt = $(this).attr("alt");
        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});
</script>

<article id="post-49" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Summer Sessions</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><img class="wp-image-1000 size-medium aligncenter" src="http://dev-department-of-music.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/courtyard-e1394649250496-300x115.jpeg" alt="" width="300" height="115" srcset="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/courtyard-e1394649250496-300x115.jpeg 300w, http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/courtyard-e1394649250496.jpeg 600w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" /></p>
<p>The Department of Music offers a roster of courses every summer, including Music 20A: Basic Musicianship, N26AC: Music in American Cultures, Music 128R (History of Jazz in America), a variety of introductory instrumental classes, and many others. You do not have to be a U.C. Berkeley student to enroll in these courses. Students interested in completing a Music Minor may choose to fulfill some or all of their minor requirements during Summer Sessions.</p>
<p>See the <a href="http://classes.berkeley.edu/search/class">Online Schedule of Classes</a> for a complete and most up-to-date course offerings.</p>
<p>See <a href="http://summer.berkeley.edu/">Summer Sessions</a> regarding application, enrollment, and other student services matters.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-49 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

<li id="menu-item-4692" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-4692"><a href="http://www.berkeley.edu/index.html">UC Berkeley</a></li>

	<li id="menu-item-4912" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-4912"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/major-program/">Music Major</a>

	<li id="menu-item-4913" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4913"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/minor-program/">Music Minor</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-4926" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-4926"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/course-information/">Course Information</a>
