<article id="post-43" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Undergraduate Degree Program</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>The Department of Music grants a B.A. degree in music and also a minor in music. We are dedicated to a liberal education in the arts and humanities, and thus involve students in all aspects of the study of music-theoretical and creative studies, historical and cultural studies, music and technology, and performance. Our curriculum is responsive to the interests of a diverse student body, and we pride ourselves on offering a broad and flexible program.</p>
<p><img class="wp-image-969 size-medium alignleft" src="http://dev-department-of-music.pantheon.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/taiko_0002-w-300x193.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="193" srcset="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/taiko_0002-w-300x193.jpg 300w, http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/taiko_0002-w.jpg 336w" sizes="(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px" />The major may serve as pre-professional training for the student seeking a career in music or provide a lasting source of enrichment for the student with other career goals. Prospective majors are asked to demonstrate a minimum standard of musical literacy in a placement test. Since we are a Department of Music rather than a School of Music, a performance audition is not required to declare the major. Lower-division studies are intended to provide grounding in the skills of musicianship and harmony and a broad background in the literature and practices of European and a variety of other music. Upper division students may choose from an extensive selection of elective courses to create an individual course of study according to their own interests. The department offers an honors program in which a major in the senior year may develop a special honors project working with a faculty adviser in any area of music studies.</p>
<p>There are a large number of double majors in the department representing fields such as Molecular and Cell Biology, Rhetoric, Physics, Theater, Dance, and Performance Studies, Political Economy of Industrial Societies, English, and Business Administration, to just name a few.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-43 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-83" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Advising</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2>Advising Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li>The Department&#8217;s <a title="Placement Procedure for Music Major Courses" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/placement-procedure-for-music-major-courses/">placement examination</a> may be taken on an advisory basis to determine level of placement in the program.</li>
<li>For advice on University and College degree requirements, entering students should consult the <a href="http://ls-advise.berkeley.edu/requirements/intro.html">College of Letters and Science</a>. College Advisors are available at 206 Evans Hall, by phone at (510) 642-1483 or via email at <a  href="javascript:smae_decode('YXNraW5zQGJlcmtlbGV5LmVkdQ==');" >&#097;&#115;&#107;&#108;&#110;&#115;&#064;&#098;&#101;&#114;&#107;&#101;&#108;&#101;&#121;&#046;&#101;&#100;&#117;</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Advisors</h2>
<h3>Undergraduate Degree Program</h3>
<p>Advising service is available, by appointment only, for general inquiries about programs of study, and the music major as well as the minor.</p>
<p>Undergraduate Advisor</p>
<p>Zoe Xu:  <a  href="javascript:smae_decode('bXVzaWNhZHZpc2luZ0BiZXJrZWxleS5lZHU=');" >&#109;&#117;&#115;&#105;&#099;&#097;&#100;&#118;&#105;&#115;&#105;&#110;&#103;&#064;&#098;&#101;&#114;&#107;&#101;&#108;&#101;&#121;&#046;&#101;&#100;&#117;</a><br />
(510) 642-2678<br />
Make an appointment: https://calendly.com/zoexu</p>
<p>Note that there is no advising appointment during the first two weeks of instructions. Music majors are required to meet with an advisor once per semester in order to release the Advising Hold for course registration. There is a high demand for advising appointments during the enrollment period. Please plan ahead and schedule your appointment a few weeks prior to your enrollment appointment in order to ensure that you meet with the advisor in a timely manner.</p>
<p>Each advising appointment is 15 minutes. To ensure that we have ample time to discuss your concerns and that the next appointment can start promptly, you will be asked to reschedule if you are more than 7 minutes late. If you know you will be late, please call ahead to see if we might be able to accommodate you.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>For mentoring in your particular area of interest, please contact any pertinent member of the Department faculty.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-83 -->

<article id="post-96" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Criteria for Musicianship Placement</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2>Requirements for placing into 52A</h2>
<p>Eligibility for placement in 52A will be determined by consideration of the following criteria as demonstrated in the student&#8217;s performance on the Musicianship Placement Test:</p>
<ul>
<li>some musical accomplishment (ability to sing, play an instrument, or compose music); and/or</li>
<li>mastery of music theory rudiments; and/or</li>
<li>aptitude for the study and performance of applied music (such as sight singing and/or ear training).</li>
</ul>
<p>And, while it is not required for entry into 52A, keyboard proficiency will be required to complete the music major, so it is strongly recommended that students avail themselves of keyboard training as soon as possible.</p>
<h2>Requirements for placing into 52B</h2>
<p>All of the above, including some keyboard proficiency, plus:</p>
<ul>
<li>Performance:
<ul>
<li>sight-sing a diatonic melody fluently;</li>
<li>at sight, sing and play (at the keyboard) fluently the bass and soprano of a Bach chorale or a simple Schubert song;</li>
<li>sing specified ascending and descending intervals up to the size of a perfect octave.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Dictation:
<ul>
<li>write down rhythm and pitches of a simple diatonic melody;</li>
<li>write down the bass, soprano and chord symbols (and rhythm!) of a diatonic chord progression and/or comparable example of music literature;</li>
<li>identify all ascending and descending intervals up to the size of a perfect octave.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h2>Requirements for placing into 152A</h2>
<p>All of the above plus:</p>
<ul>
<li>Performance:
<ul>
<li>sight sing fluently a diatonic melody with some functional chromaticism;</li>
<li>at sight, sing and play (at the keyboard) fluently bass and soprano of a more complicated song by Brahms, Wolf, or Debussy.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Dictation:
<ul>
<li>write down rhythm and pitches of a diatonic melody with some functional chromaticism;</li>
<li>write down bass, soprano, chord symbols (and rhythm) of a diatonic chord progression or comparable example of music literature which includes tonicizations (or applied or secondary dominants).</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<h2>Waive all</h2>
<p>All of the above plus:</p>
<ul>
<li>the ability to perform and write out examples of tonal music with extensive chromaticism AND atonal music; and</li>
<li>evidence of extensive performance and experience with wide variety of music.</li>
</ul>
<h2>Exam preparation</h2>
<p>The Musicianship Placement Exam is a diagnostic test to ensure that student begin in a course most appropriate for their skill level. It is not necessary for students to study extensively for the exam. However, if desired, students may use the following texts as resources for preparation:</p>
<p>Straus, Joseph Nathan. <i>Elements of music</i>. Boston: Pearson, 2014.<br />
Rogers, Nancy, and Robert W. Ottman. <i>Music for sight singing</i>. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson, 2014.<br />
Hall, Anne Carothers. <i>Studying rhythm</i>. New Jersey: Pearson Education, 2005.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-96 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

			</form>						<h2 class="widgettitle">Performance Opportunities</h2>
<div class="menu-performance-opportunities-container"><ul id="menu-performance-opportunities" class="menu"><li id="menu-item-4774" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4774"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/african-music-ensemble/">African Music Ensemble</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-4777" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4777"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/indonesian-javanese-gamelan/">Indonesian (Javanese) Gamelan</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4778" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4778"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/jazz-contemporary-improvised-music-ensemble-jcime/">Jazz &#038; Contemporary Improvised Music Ensemble (JCIME)</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4779" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4779"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-baroque-ensemble/">University Baroque Ensemble</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4784" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4784"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-chamber-chorus/">Chamber Chorus of the University of California</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-4780" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4780"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-chorus/">University Chorus</a></li>

<li id="menu-item-4782" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4782"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-wind-ensemble/">University Wind Ensemble</a></li>
</ul></div><h2 class="widgettitle">Other Performance Opportunities</h2>

<li id="menu-item-4745" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-menu-item page_item page-item-548 current_page_item menu-item-4745"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/decal-classes/">DeCal Classes</a></li>
</ul></div>		</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->

						
							
<article id="post-548" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">DeCal Classes</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><img class="alignright size-full wp-image-1016" src="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/decal1.jpg" alt="decal" width="336" height="221" srcset="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/decal1.jpg 336w, http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/decal1-300x197.jpg 300w" sizes="(max-width: 336px) 100vw, 336px" />DeCal classes provide a valuable opportunity for undergraduate students to take the initiative in the design and facilitation of academically sound courses under faculty supervision, and should be about topics not normally covered in the department&#8217;s curriculum. Music performance courses offered recently include DeCal Chamber Music for Fun (98 &amp; 198, <a title="Carillon Study" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/carillon-study/">DeCal Carillon</a> (98 &amp; 198), DeCal Chamber Orchestra (98 &amp; 198). DeCal Contemporary Pop Harmony. (DeCal classes are not necessarily offered regularly; check schedule.berkeley.edu or www.decal.org for current offerings.)</p>
<p>Course meetings, rehearsals and performances are held in the Department of Music facilities.</p>
<p>DeCal is the Program for Democratic Education at Cal. a student-run organization on the UC Berkeley campus. It is a registered student group through Office of Student Life (OSL) and is sponsored in part by the Associated Students of the University of California (ASUC); its mission is to provide support for student facilitators. Each semester over 150 accredited pass/no pass student-facilitated courses are offered on the campus. In order to facilitate a course, a student must find a faculty sponsor in a specific department. Between 3000 and 4000 UC Berkeley students take DeCals each semester.</p>
<p>For information on the University&#8217;s policies regarding DeCal classes and for required forms, see the Decal web site: <a href="http://www.decal.org">www.decal.org</a>.</p>
<h2>Procedures for Facilitators of DeCal Classes</h2>
<p><b>Department deadlines</b>:</p>
<p>Students must submit the signed and completed all required paperwork to Zoe Xu, Undergraduate Advisor, in 104 Morrison Hall by <strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">November 1st for Spring DeCal courses</span></strong> and <strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;">May 1st for Fall DeCal courses</span></strong>. This ensures proper departmental processing in order to meet the COCI deadline.</p>
<p>Please make an appointment with Zoe at https://calendly.com/zoexu to review your DeCal paperwork. Electronic, late, or incomplete submission will not be considered.</p>
<p>The department will notify student facilitators regarding the approval status of their DeCal courses by December 20th for Spring DeCal courses and July 1st by Fall DeCal courses. Please see &#8220;Class Scheduling&#8221; below for information on scheduling DeCal courses.</p>
<p><strong>Required paperwork:</strong></p>
<p>Students must also complete and include all the following forms in the DeCal proposal packet:</p>
<p>1. <a href="https://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/course_proposal_form_packet_2017.pdf">Course Proposal Packet</a>, signed by your faculty sponsor.</p>
<p>2. Detailed course syllabus. Please consult the Center for Teaching and Learning <a href="http://teaching.berkeley.edu/syllabus" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">guidelines for creating a syllabus</a> or syllabi for your undergraduate classes.</p>
<ul>
<li>Generally, a syllabus should include the following information:
<ul>
<li>Course Description: A paragraph or two that describes the course objectives and content.</li>
<li>Course Schedule: Frequency and length of class meetings (e.g., TuTh 6-8pm, 3105 Tolman Hall).</li>
<li>Course Outline: Outline of each week&#8217;s topic that includes reading(s) required for that week and/or planned activities and discussions.</li>
<li>Assignments: Clear Description of each assignment, including requirements, due date, and the percentage it will contribute to the final grade.</li>
<li>Performance Evaluation Guideline: How will student performance be evaluated; a grading rubric as applicable.</li>
<li>Reading List: If applicable.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<ul>
<li>More information may be included in the syllabus as appropriate.</li>
</ul>
<p>3. Responses to the seven questions listed on the Course Proposal Form. If responses can be found in the syllabus, you should clearly indicate which section of the syllabus can an answer be found. If responses are not incorporated into the syllabus, they must be typed on a separate sheet of paper. Please leave Question #7 in the Course Proposal Form blank until you have met with the Undergraduate Advisor.</p>
<p>4. Unit Value Worksheet (p.2 of the Course Proposal Packet).</p>
<p>5. <a href="https://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/faculty_sponsor_letter.2017.pdf">A letter of support from the faculty sponsor</a>. See instructions in p.5 of the Course Proposal Packet: Faculty Checklist.</p>
<p>5. <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/DeCalSchedForm_v17Fa.pdf">Music Decal Class Scheduling Worksheet</a><span style="line-height: 1.5;">. </span><span style="line-height: 1.5;">Your application will be considered incomplete without this form.</span></p>
<p>Please only use the most current version of these forms.</p>
<p><strong>Obtaining Departmental and Academic Senate Approval:</strong></p>
<p>You are only responsible for obtaining the faculty sponsor signature. The Undergraduate Advisor will review your DeCal proposal packet, submit to the Department Chair for review, and forward to the Academic Senate. Please do not submit directly to the Department Chair or Academic Senate. If the Department Chair is also the faculty sponsor of your DeCal course, you are still required to meet with the Undergraduate Advisor and turn in your DeCal proposal packet.</p>
<p><strong>Class Scheduling:</strong></p>
<p>The information on your Music DeCal Questionnaire will be used to schedule the class. Once the class is set up, the Department Scheduler will contact you regarding the course CCN and meeting day/time, and the Operations Manager regarding the room reservation, respectively.</p>
<p><strong>Publishing Your Course:</strong></p>
<p>To publish your course on the DeCal website, please submit a copy of the approved proposal to the Program for Democratic Education at Cal located in 112 Hearst Gym Station 15.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Student Musical Activities (SMA)</h2>
<p>Student Musical Activities (SMA), part of Cal Performances, is comprised of three distinct programs designed to offer over five hundred students, faculty, staff and alumni members the opportunity to experience a wide array of musical education and performance opportunities at the University of California at Berkeley. SMA is home to the University of California Marching Band, UC Jazz Ensembles, and UC Choral Ensembles, which include the University of California Men&#8217;s Octet, UC Men&#8217;s Chorale, the Cal Jazz Choir, BareStage, UC Women&#8217;s Chorale, the California Golden Overtones, Perfect Fifth, Noteworthy and UC Alumni Chorus.</p>
<p>Check the <a href="http://www.sma.berkeley.edu/sma/">SMA website</a> for specific participation and audition information for each group.</p>
<p><b>University of California Jazz Ensemble (SMA)</b>: <a href="http://ucjazz.berkeley.edu/ucjazz.html">http://ucjazz.berkeley.edu/ucjazz.html</a><br />
<b>University of California Marching Bands (SMA)</b>: <a href="http://www.calband.berkeley.edu/calband/">http://www.calband.berkeley.edu/calband/</a><br />
<b>University of California Choral Ensembles (SMA)</b>: <a href="http://ucchoral.berkeley.edu/ucchoral/">http://ucchoral.berkeley.edu/ucchoral/</a></p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-548 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

</li>
<li id="menu-item-4660" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-4660"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/">Performance Opportunities</a>

<article id="post-108" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Frequently Asked Questions</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2>General Questions</h2>
<p><strong>What is the difference between a Department of Music and a School of Music?</strong><br />
A Department of Music is likely to be a smaller academic unit, situated within a liberal arts educational environment. A School of Music is essentially a conservatory (i.e.., focused on training professional performers) that is situated within a University A Department of Music such as ours, for example, offers a Bachelor of Arts degree while a School of Music may offer both a Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Music degree.</p>
<p><strong>What is the relationship between admissions to the University and declaration of the major?</strong><br />
The Undergraduate Admissions Office handles admission to the College of Letters and Science. For information, see admissions information.<br />
Students can declare the major when they have enrolled in 49B and 49C. In order to enroll in these courses, the student must have taken the Placement Exam and placed into 49B.</p>
<p><strong>What is the balance between theoretical knowledge and experiential knowledge in the Department of Music&#8217;s program?</strong></p>
<p>There are many opportunities to apply both. Connections are constantly made between the theory of music and our experiences of it in sound either as a listener or practitioner. Musicianship training (learning to hear and notate, to sing from notation at sight, to listen analytically) comes into use in harmony courses, in history and culture courses, and in performance study. Study of harmony involves musical creativity as well as analysis, often of repertoire that is being performed in our context. Theory, listening skills, analytical skills are important no matter what musical repertoires are being studied.</p>
<p><strong>What are some extracurricular music opportunities at the university?</strong></p>
<p>The Undergraduate Composers organize concerts each semester in which Cal students perform pieces by students.<br />
Free noon concerts take place in Hertz Hall every Wednesday. Performers must be affiliated with UC Berkeley, and audition during the semester preceding their proposed concert. Student recitals are also presented in 125 Morrison Hall.<br />
There are many DeCal classes that have to do with music. In order to supplement your classical and theory knowledge, it is a good idea to check out the DeCal classes for hip-hop, funk, or spoken poetry that are usually offered. The list of classes changes, but make sure to take a look at the classes every semester. Their website is: <a href="http://www.decal.org/">http://www.decal.org/</a>.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Music Major</h2>
<p><strong>When and how can I declare the major?</strong></p>
<p>See <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/major-declaration/">Major Declaration</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Can I declare a concentration in composition, ethnomusicology, musicology, or performance?</strong><br />
The only &#8220;declaration&#8221; process is the declaration of the music major.. All music majors receive a B.A. in Music. If they wish, students may design a concentration or specialization based on individual interests, but this is an informal process. Upper division courses in each of the fields listed above are offered every semester. Consult undergraduate careers for planning suggestions, or meet with a faculty member to discuss options. Students are encouraged to select a faculty mentor who will help guide them along the chosen path. This is particularly important for students who are interested in pursuing graduate studies or considering a career in music.</p>
<p><strong>How big are the major classes in the Department of Music?</strong><br />
Music major courses in musicianship and theory are restricted to fewer than twenty students. Upper division major seminars are smaller. History and culture courses range from 30 to 100 students. Enrollment in performance ensembles is appropriate to the repertoire that be performed and its instrumentation. Our teachers know the students and vice versa. We are a relatively intimate department within the large university.</p>
<p><strong>Is it possible to double major, and still graduate in four years?</strong><br />
Yes, many music majors successfully complete a second major in four years. It often takes careful planning, because the music major has many lower division requirements. Be sure to check in with the Undergraduate Advisor in the Music Department and in L&amp;S as you choose your courses each semester.</p>
<p><strong>What are the degree requirements and policies of the major and the university?</strong><br />
The music department is part of the College of Letters and Science and awards Bachelor&#8217;s of Arts degrees (B.A.&#8217;s) to undergraduate students. There are four sets of requirements: those required by all campuses of the University of California, those required specifically at UC Berkeley, those of the College of Letters and Science, and those of the music department. To earn your degree, you must successfully complete the music major requirements as well as the the university, Berkeley campus, and College of Letters &amp; Science requirements. For the first of three sets of requirements, please consult: <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/ls-office-undergraduate-advising">http://ls.berkeley.edu/?q=undergraduate/degree-requirements-policies</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Do you need piano skills to be a music major? If not, what options are there for you to learn how to play the piano?</strong><br />
You do not necessarily need prior piano experience, although having some will make the work a lot easier for you. There is a piano class, Music 405, that gives music majors the opportunity to learn basic piano technique in a group lesson setting. This class is highly recommended for those with little or no piano experience.</p>
<p><strong>If I want to take private lessons as music major, how do I do that?</strong><br />
Private instruction is provided for the most skilled musicians among our majors under the course number Music 150. Music 150 is a personalized performance program for the intermediate to advanced performer. Each student works individually with a private instructor while participating in one of the performance ensembles listed above. To enroll, students must be declared music majors.</p>
<p><strong>How can majors participate in the governance of the Department of Music?</strong><br />
There is an opportunity as an undergraduates to serve as the Undergraduate Representative on the Undergraduate Committee. This committee holds monthly meetings to discuss issues that directly affect the undergraduate music program. It is made up of a few student representatives as well as staff and faculty members. This is a good place to let your voice be heard and to discuss the opportunities available to undergraduate music students.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Music Minor</h2>
<p><strong>What is the process to waive Music 20A/B? </strong></p>
<p>See &#8220;Exemption from lower division requirements&#8221; under the <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/minor-program/">Music Minor Program</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Should I pre-enroll in Music 20A before scheduling the waiver exam?</strong></p>
<p>Music 20A classes are usually enrolled in capacity with a substantial waitlist. Students should pre-enroll in the class even if they attempt to waive the requirement.</p>
<p><strong>Will I be able to waive Music 20A/B?</strong></p>
<p>Students should review the <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/Music-20A-Su16.Sample.pdf">Music 20A sample syllabus</a> to see if they have already mastered the content covered in the course, thereby assessing their ability to obtain the waiver.</p>
<p><strong>Are performance courses in the 140 series repeatable? Can I repeat one for the minor requirement?</strong></p>
<p>Performance courses (Music 140-149, 164, 165) are repeatable without restrictions, meaning that you can repeat it as many times as you with. Students can, and should, review the repeat rule of each course in the <a href="http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/music/">Berkeley Academic Guide</a>.</p>
<p>Students may count a repeatable course toward the minor a maximum of 3 times, regardless of how many times they repeat the course.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2></h2>
<h2>Performance &amp; Performance Courses</h2>
<p><strong>What performance opportunities are available in the Department of Music?</strong><br />
The Department offers ensemble courses (the Music 140 series) that are available to all students on the campus, both majors and non-majors alike. Music majors can perform individually or as part of larger ensembles for course credit. All majors must complete three semesters of performance ensemble requirement, but are encouraged to do more. For-credit ensembles are African Music Ensemble, Contemporary Improvisation Ensemble, Gospel Choir, Javanese Gamelan, University Baroque Ensemble, University Chorus, University Symphony, and University Wind Ensemble. Other major courses that involve performance are Jazz Theory and Performance (116AM/BM), Conducting (161A/B), Improvisation (164), Baroque Music Performance (171D), composer or genre studies that include performance of the music (180 series), and world music courses that include 11 weeks of performance lab (131-9).</p>
<p><strong>I&#8217;m interested in joining an ensemble or enrolling in a performance course. Do I have to audition?</strong></p>
<p>Enrollment in the Music 140 series and 150 are audition-based. See <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/audition-information/">Audition Information</a> for more information. Information on the upcoming auditions is usually updated on the webpage in early August for Fall semesters and early January for Spring semesters.</p>
<p>With the exception of Music 148, students may choose to pre-enroll in a class in the Music 140 series before auditioning, or add the class after they pass the audition. In either scenario, students are responsible for adjusting their enrollment accordingly by the <a href="http://registrar.berkeley.edu/calendar">student enrollment deadlines</a>. It is imperative that students observe these deadlines as they are strictly enforced. Students interested in taking Music 148 are advised to pre-enroll in the course.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Placement Procedures and Auditions</h2>
<p><strong>What does the Musicianship Placement Exam require?<br />
</strong>The written and practical exam determines the courses that will be the best fit for you in your first semester. You will display your background in music theory, musicianship and performance, and piano. See <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/placement-procedure-for-music-major-courses/">Placement Procedures</a>.</p>
<p><strong>I will be taking the Musicianship Placement Exam for the first time this upcoming semester. What classes should I sign up for during my enrollment appointment?</strong></p>
<p>You should pre-enroll in Music 52A (Musicianship I) and Music 53A (Harmony I) prior to taking the exam. If you read the <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/criteria-for-musicianship-placement/">musicianship placement criteria</a> and <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/placement-procedure-for-music-major-courses/criteria-for-harmony-placement/">harmony placement criteria</a> and are reasonably confident that you may place above either, pre-enroll in the course that you believe you would place in. You will be able to adjust you enrollment when placement results become available.</p>
<p>Note that you are responsible for making changes to your class schedule and adhering to the <a href="http://registrar.berkeley.edu/calendar">student enrollment deadlines</a>. Never assume that you would be automatically added to or dropped from a class.</p>
<p><strong>Can I repeat the Musicianship Placement Exam?</strong></p>
<p>Yes, the Musicianship Placement Exam is a diagnostic test and students can repeat it in the following semester. However, if you do not place into a desired level of after two attempts, please consult the Undergraduate Advisor and a musicianship faculty regarding the best course of action to pursue your educational goals.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Course Information and Enrollment</h2>
<p><strong>I&#8217;m interested in taking this undergraduate Music course but it&#8217;s not listed in the <a href="http://classes.berkeley.edu/search/class">Class Schedule</a>. Will it be offered?</strong></p>
<p>Not all courses are offered in a given semester. If a class is not listed in the <a href="http://classes.berkeley.edu/search/class">Class Schedule</a> for a given semester, it is not offered in that semester.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-108 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<div id="main" class="group">

				<div class="page">
								<div id="sidebar" class="widget-area" role="complementary">

				</div>
			</form>						<h2 class="widgettitle"><a class="rsswidget" href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/rss/sn/music/type/future?filter=Sponsor&#038;filtersel=202"><img class="rss-widget-icon" style="border:0" width="14" height="14" src="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-includes/images/rss.png" alt="RSS" /></a> <a class="rsswidget" href="http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/music.html">Upcoming Events</a></h2>
<ul><li><a class='rsswidget' href='http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/music.html?event_ID=110611&#038;date=2017-12-06'>Noon Concert: Holiday Choral Concert, Dec 6</a></li><li><a class='rsswidget' href='http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/music.html?event_ID=110612&#038;date=2017-12-06'>University Baroque Ensemble, Dec 6</a></li><li><a class='rsswidget' href='http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/music.html?event_ID=110615&#038;date=2017-12-08'>University Symphony Orchestra, Dec 8-9</a></li><li><a class='rsswidget' href='http://events.berkeley.edu/index.php/calendar/sn/music.html?event_ID=110618&#038;date=2017-12-11'>CANCELED: Berkeley New Music Project, Dec 11</a></li></ul>				<h2 class="widgettitle">of Note</h2>
		<ul>
					<li>
				<a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/carillon-marks-centennial-in-november-looks-toward-future-2/">Carillon Marks Centennial in November; Looks Toward Future</a>
						</li>
					<li>
				<a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/september-2017-enewsletter/">September 2017 eNewsletter</a>
						</li>
					<li>
				<a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/taruskin-wins-esteemed-kyoto-prize/">Taruskin Wins Esteemed Kyoto Prize</a>
						</li>
					<li>
				<a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/class-of-2017-by-the-numbers/">Class of 2017: By the Numbers</a>
						</li>
				</ul>
						</div><!-- #secondary .widget-area -->

						
							
<article id="post-4301" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Honors Program in Music</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>Students with a 3.5 GPA in the major and 3.3 GPA overall may apply for admission to the Honors Program.</p>
<p>The award of departmental Honors is contingent upon submission of a thesis or project of high quality, based upon independent study with a member of the Music Department&#8217;s faculty and marked by satisfactory completion of Music H195. The faculty sponsor will evaluate whether the project is of Honors quality. Departmental Honors designations will be included in the student&#8217;s permanent UC Berkeley record. The Music Department maintains a file of select completed Honors theses, which are available for review.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Courses</strong></p>
<p>Students are required to enroll in Music H195 (4 units) in the semester in which they complete the thesis. In case of a year-long project as agreed upon in the application proposal, honors candidates may repeat the course once. Music H195 may be used to count toward the 24 upper-division units required for the major <span style="text-decoration: underline"><strong>once</strong></span>; if repeated, only one Music H195 class may count toward upper division electives.</p>
<p>Upon conclusion of the project, students are required to submit the work to their faculty sponsor for evaluation, and furnish a copy to the Music Department for archive. Submit the archive copy to 104 Morrison no later than 1 week after final grades are released.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Suggested Timeline</strong></p>
<p><strong><em><u>Junior Year (Spring):</u></em></strong><br />
Set a thesis topic; outline thesis project.<br />
Secure a faculty sponsor</p>
<p><strong><em><u>Summer between Junior and Senior Year:</u></em></strong><br />
Work on the design of the project</p>
<p><strong><em><u>Senior Year (Fall or Spring):</u></em></strong><br />
Enroll in Music H195 (application due 3<span style="font-size: 13.3333px">rd</span> week). For semester-long projects, students may choose to complete the thesis in Fall or Spring and enroll in Music H195 in the same semester. For year-long projects, students should start in the Fall semester.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p><strong>Application</strong></p>
<p>Students must complete a signed Special Studies Application to enroll in Music H195 and attach a project proposal. Forms are available for pickup at the reception area in 104 Morrison during business hours (Monday-Friday, 9am-12pm, and 1-4pm).</p>
<p>Students must submit the application and an outline of the research proposal for approval to their Music faculty sponsor prior to submitting to the Undergraduate Advisor. The project proposal should outline a specific plan and include the following information:</p>
<ul>
<li>Project objectives, description, and scope</li>
<li>Work procedures/methodology</li>
<li>Tentative timeline</li>
<li>Student&#8217;s responsibility</li>
<li>Faculty sponsor&#8217;s commitment</li>
<li>Additional readings/requirements (if applicable)</li>
</ul>
<p><span style="text-decoration: underline">Sample Questions to consider in your proposal:</span></p>
<ul>
<li>What question(s) will your thesis attempt to address?</li>
<li>Will there be collaboration with other individuals, such as fellow students or graduate students, etc.? Keep in mind that the honors thesis must be your original, independent work. You must articulate any potential collaboration.</li>
<li>What coursework, which you have completed, is relevant to your study?</li>
<li>How will the faculty sponsor be involved, support, or supervisor your endeavor?</li>
</ul>
<div class="tb f29"></div>
<div class="tb f33"><strong>Signed applications are due to the Music Department front office at 104 Morrison by 12pm on the Friday of the 3rd week of instruction.</strong></div>
<p>The completed application will be reviewed for approval (primarily GPA eligibility). Once approved, enrollment information will be emailed to students. It is the student&#8217;s responsibility to enroll in the course as soon as the information is received but no later than the Add/Drop Deadline.</p>
<p><strong>Faculty Sponsor</strong></p>
<p>Students should maintain close contact with their faculty sponsor to ensure clear communication on the direction of the thesis project and expectations of the professor. Students are encouraged to submit a draft of the honors thesis to the instructor mid-semester for comments before the final copy is produced.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-4301 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-102" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Information for Transfer Students</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2>Potential Transfer Students</h2>
<p>Preparation for transfer students should include work in:</p>
<ul>
<li>Musicianship</li>
<li>Harmony</li>
<li>Western and Non-Western Music History</li>
</ul>
<p>Placement in the musicianship series (49B, 50, 51) and the harmony series (49C, 60, 61) at Berkeley is determined by the department <a title="Placement Procedure for Music Major Courses" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/placement-procedure-for-music-major-courses/">placement exam</a>, not by previous coursework.</p>
<p>The description of the placement exams and the criteria for placement can function as a guide for students in their preparation. <strong>It is important that transfer students be able to place into 49B during their first semester.</strong> Those who do not will need to take 20A before beginning the major sequence of classes for musicianship and harmony, which may prolong their completion of degree requirements.</p>
<p>Students who are able to come to the Berkeley campus may take the department&#8217;s placement exam on an advisory basis at the beginning of any semester.</p>
<h2>Entering Transfer Students</h2>
<p><a title="Placement Procedure for Music Major Courses" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/placement-procedure-for-music-major-courses/">Music Placement Procedure</a>: All entering transfer students intending to major in music must be prepared to take the first four parts of the department&#8217;s placement procedure on the day before instruction begins. Students with little or no keyboard experience should also take the Piano 405 placement exam, which usually takes place during the first week of term.</p>
<p>These exams determine the student&#8217;s placement in or exemption from the lower division musicianship and harmony series and also serve as an audition for the department&#8217;s performance classes.</p>
<h2>Transfer Advisor</h2>
<p>All new transfer students must schedule an appointment with Zoe Xu <a href="https://calendly.com/zoexu" target="_blank">online</a> during the first month of classes to plan a strategy for completing the major.</p>
<p>Students should bring with them:</p>
<ul>
<li>a copy of their transcript (official or unofficial)</li>
<li>a syllabus and exams/papers from courses taken in the History of Western Music</li>
</ul>
<h2>Registering for classes</h2>
<p>Until they know the results of the placement exam, students should register for:</p>
<ul>
<li>49B Musicianship I</li>
<li>49C Harmony I</li>
</ul>
<p>Students will be able to make adjustments to their course schedule during the add/drop period to reflect the placement exam.</p>
<p>In addition students may sign up for the following kinds of courses:</p>
<ul>
<li><a title="Performance Courses" href="http://localhost/wordpress2/ucbmusic/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/performance-courses/">Performance courses</a></li>
<li>Music Cultures courses numbered between Music 130-139. (Note: these courses satisfy both a lower division music cultures requirement as well as upper division music electives.)</li>
<li>Music 75-77. (Note: these courses may have prerequisites!)</li>
<li>An upper division American Cultures course outside the music department. This is a university requirement which all students must satisfy.</li>
</ul>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-102 -->

<div id="wrapper" class="hfeed">
	
<header id="site-header" class="home wideness" role="banner">
	 <h1><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu">  Major Declaration</a></h1>
			<nav id="main-nav" role="navigation">
				<div class="menu-main-menu-custom-header-menu-container"><ul id="menu-main-menu-custom-header-menu" class="sf-menu"><li id="menu-item-4628" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-home menu-item-4628"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/">Home</a></li>

<article id="post-3447" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Major Declaration</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><img class="alignright size-full wp-image-974" src="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/rosnak-mu50_0194-w.jpg" alt="rosnak-mu50_0194-w" width="336" height="223" srcset="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/rosnak-mu50_0194-w.jpg 336w, http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/rosnak-mu50_0194-w-300x199.jpg 300w" sizes="(max-width: 336px) 100vw, 336px" />All students intending to major in music must follow the <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/placement-procedure-for-music-major-courses/">Music placement procedure</a> before beginning music major classes. This procedure places students in the musicianship and harmony sequences, and determines whether supplemental classes in piano are recommended.</p>
<p>Note that the Musicianship Placement Exam is administered once before the beginning of each semester; it is mandatory for prospective music majors and students should plan their school break accordingly in order to attend.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h3>Major Declaration Procedure</h3>
<p>To declare the Music Major, prospective students must:</p>
<ul>
<li>Place into Music 52A (formerly 49B) or higher via the Musicianship Placement Exam, and enroll in the course of placement.</li>
<li>Submit the Intent to Declare the Music Major form to the Undergraduate Advisor as soon as possible after placement.</li>
<li>Complete at least 3 required courses with a grade of C or above in each course. The 3 courses must represent 3 different areas of study:
<ul>
<li>Musicianship and Harmony</li>
<li>Music History (Music 70)</li>
<li>Musics of the World (Music 80)</li>
<li>Performance</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>During Fall 2017 – Spring 2018, students who are wait-listed for Music 70 or 80 may choose the following course substitutes to fulfill major declaration requirements:</p>
<ul>
<li>Music 70: substituted with 170 or 170A</li>
<li>Music 80: substituted with 130-139, or 180</li>
</ul>
<p>Students must obtain permission from the Undergraduate Advisor prior to choosing this substitution. Student must obtain a C or higher in both the substitute course(s) <u>AND</u>Music 70 as well as 80 to remain in good standing with the major.</p>
<p>An Undergraduate Orientation is held once before the beginning of each semester. The orientation reviews important information such as placement exams, major requirements, program planning, major resources, and student life. It is imperative that prospective music majors make every possible effort to attend.</p>
<p><strong>Major Declaration Timeline:</strong></p>
<p>The minimum amount of time required to complete all declaration requirements is one semester. Because intended music majors must receive a grade of C or higher in each required course, they will officially declared in the major in the months following the end of the semester, after final grades are released.</p>
<table style="height: 169px;" width="550">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="221"><strong>Intent to Declare form submitted</strong></td>
<td width="221"><strong>Officially declared if eligible</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="221">Fall semester</td>
<td width="221">Usually January of the following year</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="221">Spring semester</td>
<td width="221">Usually June</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="221">Summer semester</td>
<td width="221">Usually September</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>It is expected that most students will be able to complete all declaration requirements within a year, and transfer students should strive to complete the requirements in one semester. Students should seek consultation with the Undergraduate Advisor as soon as possible if this is not feasible for their individual circumstances.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-3447 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<article id="post-89" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Major Program</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h3>Undergraduate Student Learning Goals for the Music Major</h3>
<ol>Berkeley music majors are expected:</p>
<li>To acquire knowledge and understanding of music in an integrated way—through historical and cultural studies, musicianship and theory, and performance.  These studies prepare students to pursue a career in some aspect of music or to maintain music as a central part of their lives.</li>
<li>To cultivate musical competency, including literacy (the use of music notation in reading, performing, composing, analyzing, and hearing music). Areas of courses include:
<ul>
<li>Musicianship</li>
<li>Harmony</li>
<li>Piano proficiency</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>To develop skills of critical thinking and writing about music by taking courses on past and present musical cultures in European and other heritages. Areas of courses include:
<ul>
<li>Introduction to selected musics of the world</li>
<li>Western music history</li>
<li>Upper division electives</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>To create music by performing, composing, and improvising. Areas of courses include:
<ul>
<li>Musicianship</li>
<li>Harmony</li>
<li>Performance ensembles</li>
<li>Upper division electives in historical and cultural studies, music and technology, theory, conducting, and improvisation</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>To pursue personal interests by selecting upper-division courses, including independent studies and honors projects.</li>
</ol>
<h2><strong>How Music Majors Are Assessed</strong></h2>
<ol>
<li>Placement exams at the outset of studies assess students’ musical competence, and determine their place in the required lower-division theory and harmony courses.</li>
<li>Admission to performance ensembles (upper-division performance courses) is by audition.  Assessment is based on successful public performances.</li>
<li>An audition is required to enroll in Music 150—the performance courses that offer private instruction to the most skilled majors, as well as large and small ensemble experience. Assessment is based on successful public performances.</li>
<li>Students who show exceptional ability in musicianship can be selected to participate in a peer tutoring program for credit.  This provides a capstone experience for students interested in teaching, as well as providing yet more support for other music students.</li>
<li>In required and elective seminars, critical thinking and writing is assessed when students present a major independent project at the end of term.</li>
<li>Compositional skills are assessed through the rehearsal and public performance of student works.</li>
</ol>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-89 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

	<footer id="footer" class="wideness" role="contentinfo">

<li id="menu-item-4692" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-4692"><a href="http://www.berkeley.edu/index.html">UC Berkeley</a></li>

	<ul class="sub-menu">
		<li id="menu-item-4910" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4910"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/major-declaration/">Major Declaration</a></li>
		<li id="menu-item-4911" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4911"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/major-requirements-fa16-startup/">Major Requirements (Fa&#8217;16 Startup)</a></li>
		<li id="menu-item-5280" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page current-menu-item page_item page-item-3425 current_page_item menu-item-5280"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/major-requirements-sp16-prior/">Major Requirements (Sp&#8217;16 &#038; Prior)</a></li>
		<li id="menu-item-5184" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-5184"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/program-planning/">Program Planning</a></li>
	</ul>

<article id="post-3425" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Major Requirements (Sp&#8217;16 &#038; Prior)</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<h2>Requirements for the Music Major</h2>
<h3>Applicable students admitted to UC Berkeley in Spring 2016 or prior</h3>
<h4>Lower Division</h4>
<ul>
<li>Musicianship series (49B, 50, 51)</li>
<li>Harmony series (49C, 60, 61)</li>
<li>History and Culture series: 4 courses from 73-77 as follows:
<ul>
<li>76 (18th and 19th Centuries)</li>
<li>One section of 73-74 (topics in the musics of the world)
<ul>
<li>Note: Junior Transfers must take upper division equivalent (Music 130-139).</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>75 (music to 1700) or 77 (20th Century)</li>
<li>Another section of 73-74 or the remaining course in Western history</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p><b>All courses counting towards Music Major lower and upper division requirements must be taken for a letter grade. A letter grade of C- or higher must be received in all of your lower and upper division Music Major courses. Additionally, students must maintain a 2.0 GPA in the major to be in good standing. </b></p>
<p>The first semester of the major is an integrated introductory course that combines musicianship (49B) and harmony (49C). It is recommended that students with limited keyboard skills take Music 405 as well. Students are required to make an appointment with a Music Department Advisior at the beginning of their first semester to plan their program for future semesters. Students will go on to develop their basic skills with two additional semesters of both musicianship (50, 51) and harmony (60, 61). At the same time, they will broaden their knowledge of past and present musical cultures with four courses from the 73-77 series. All majors must take Music 76 (Western music history 1700-1900). In addition they must choose one or two courses from the Music 73-74 series (Music of Africa, Caribbean, Japan, Middle East, etc), and one or two from Music 75 (Western music history 900-1700) and 77 (Western music history 1900 to the present).</p>
<p>Students without keyboard proficiency are strongly urged to enroll in two semesters of basic piano (Music 405) in their first semesters in the major program.</p>
<h4>Upper Division (24 units)</h4>
<ul>
<li>One seminar from the 170-189 series</li>
<li>21 additional units of music major courses from 130-189 and upper division music courses from 100-129 with an M suffix. Students must include at least three performance classes in the 140 series or in conjunction with the 150 series.</li>
</ul>
<p>All students must complete one course from the 170-180 series (seminars in analysis and performance), which offer more focused study of a composer or musical genre of Western or non-Western music, taught from a variety of perspectives.</p>
<p>In addition students are required to take three semesters of performance from the 140 (2 units) or 150 (2-3 units) series, provided that they are in an ensemble in conjunction with their 150 lessons. Although these courses are upper division, they may be taken at any point in the student&#8217;s career. The 140 series consists of the department&#8217;s large performance ensembles and is open both to majors and non-majors. The 150 series is for music majors (by audition) who would like to receive subsidized lessons and coaching and also participate in smaller chamber ensembles. See <a title="Performance Courses" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/performance-courses/">Performance Program for Music Majors</a> for more information.</p>
<p>Most significant to the completion of the music major&#8217;s course of study are the remaining elective units necessary to reach a total of at least 24 upper division units in the major. These courses are to be chosen from those numbered 130-189 or from those courses numbered 100-129 with an &#8220;M&#8221; designation. Students are expected to shape their program according to their particular interests, using these units and, if they wish, additional courses from both within and outside the department (with departmental approval). Suggested areas of specialization include composition, musics of the world, western music history, conducting, performance , improvisation, theory and analysis, cognitive science and music technology. At least once every semester students need to meet with their advisers to discuss their program, obtain their advisor codes and have their elective courses approved.</p>
<p>The College of Letters and Science requires that all music majors complete 36 upper division units. In addition to the 24 units required for the music major (see above), students must complete 6 units that are outside of the major, and 6 units that are either in or out of the major.</p>
<p>For those thinking of graduate school or a career in music the department has outlined a number of programs of study at the <a title="Undergraduate Careers" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/undergraduate-careers/">careers page</a>.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-3425 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<li id="menu-item-4660" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-4660"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/">Performance Opportunities</a>

<article id="post-92" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Music Minor</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p>Students may choose to complete a minor in Music, which consists of a total of 8 courses (3 lower-division and 5 upper-division courses).</p>
<h2>General program policies</h2>
<p><img class="size-full wp-image-976 alignright" src="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/02/music20pract-w.jpg" alt="music20pract-w" width="336" height="316" srcset="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/music20pract-w.jpg 336w, http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/music20pract-w-300x282.jpg 300w" sizes="(max-width: 336px) 100vw, 336px" /></p>
<ol>
<li>All courses applied to the Music Minor requirements must be taken for a letter grade. A letter grade of C- or higher must be received in all of your lower- and upper-division music minor courses. If a Music course is taken as Pass/No Pass, it cannot be accepted in satisfaction of the minor requirement and students must take an alternative course that fulfills the same requirement for a letter grade.</li>
<li>A minimum 2.0 grade point average is required for courses included in the Music Minor.</li>
<li>A minimum three of the five upper-division courses must be completed at Berkeley. Performance courses must be taken at Berkeley.</li>
<li>No more than one upper-division course may be included in both your minor and major program.</li>
</ol>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Minor requirements</h2>
<h3>Lower Division Course Requirements</h3>
<p>The lower division courses for the music minor are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Music 20A</li>
<li>Music 20B <b>or</b> Music 25A <b>and</b></li>
<li>Music 26AC<strong>, </strong>Music 27<strong>or</strong> Music 29.</li>
</ul>
<p>Courses for the music major may be substituted for the equivalent minor course (on left) if student has placed 49B or higher on the <a title="Placement Procedure for Music Major Courses" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/placement-procedure-for-music-major-courses/">Music Placement Procedure</a>.</p>
<table summary="">
<tbody>
<tr>
<th>MUSIC MINOR COURSES</th>
<th>MUSIC MAJOR COURSE EQUIVALENT</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>20A &#8211; Basic Musicianship</td>
<td>52A (49B) &#8211; Musicianship. Must be taken concurrently with 53A (49C) or 25A, or after 25A or 53A (49C) (see below).</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>20B &#8211; Basic Musicianship, <strong>OR</strong><br />
25A &#8211; Introduction to Music Theory. (20A must be taken before 25A)</td>
<td>53A (49C) &#8211; Harmony. Must be taken before 52A (49B) or concurrently.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>27 &#8211; Introduction to Western Music, <strong>OR</strong><br />
26AC &#8211; Music in American Culture, <strong>OR </strong>29 &#8211; Music Now</td>
<td>70 or 80 with instructor approval.*</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p>*Under rare circumstances, Music 70 and 80 may be used as substitution with instructor approval. However, both courses are requirements for the Music Major; enrollment in these two courses are highly competitive and prioritize declared/intended Music Majors. Prerequisites of Music 70: students must have taken and passed the Musicianship Placement Exam; be fluent in reading music notation; or have consent of instructor. Prerequisite of Music 80: for music majors and intended music majors only.</p>
<p>The Music Placement Exam is given in 125 Morrison at 9 am the day before instruction begins during the Fall and Spring semesters. Come prepared with a piece to play or sing, and a pencil with an eraser. For more information, see the <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate/placementproc.php">Music Placement Procedure</a> page.</p>
<h3>Upper Division Course Requirements</h3>
<p><strong>All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade.</strong><b> A letter grade of C- or higher must be received in all of your lower and upper division music minor courses. </b></p>
<p>A minimum of 5 upper division music courses (100-149).</p>
<ul>
<li>At least one course <b>must</b> be in the 140 series.</li>
<li>At least one course <b>must not</b> be in the 140 series.</li>
<li>Courses that may be repeated for credit may count towards the minor a maximum of three times. Check the repeat rule of each course in the <a href="http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/music/">Berkeley Academic Guide</a>.</li>
<li>Three of the five upper division courses must be completed at UC Berkeley.</li>
</ul>
<p>Upper division courses designed primarily for music majors (151-189) may be substituted if the student has met the prerequisites or has the permission of the instructor.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Exemption from lower division requirements</h2>
<p>We do not accept course substitution by AP Music Theory or coursework from community college. However, Music 20A and B may be waived by examination. The Music 20A/B Minor Waiver Exam is a 15-minute oral test. It is appropriate for intending minors who:</p>
<ul>
<li>Have some musical accomplishment (ability to sing, play an instrument or compose music) and mastery of music theory rudiments;</li>
<li>Sing music at sight in major &amp; minor modes, and in simple &amp; compound meters;</li>
<li>Identify major and minor key signatures; sing and spell major and three forms of minor scales in any key; sing and identify intervals; sing and spell chord functions in various keys, e.g. &#8220;sing and spell iv and V7 in the key of F-sharp minor.&#8221;</li>
</ul>
<p>The sample syllabus for Music 20A is available at <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/course-information/">Course Information</a>. Students with questions about their ability to obtain the waiver should review the syllabus and see if they have already mastered the content covered in the course.</p>
<p>Students may not waive Music 25A. Those with training in four-part harmony writing who would like to place out of 25A should take the <a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/placement-procedure-for-music-major-courses/">Advanced Placement Harmony Exam</a>. If placed out of 25A or 53A, students should take the next level of harmony course.</p>
<p><strong>To request Music 20A/B waiver, please contact Prof. Matthew Hough at hough@berkeley.edu.</strong></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2>Procedure for Declaration and Confirmation of the Minor</h2>
<p>Unlike a major, there is no formal &#8220;declaration&#8221; of intent to minor in Music. Students can, and should, start taking required Music courses prior to declaration.</p>
<p>Students declare the Music Minor by completing a <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/advcompletionoflnsminor.pdf">Completion of L&amp;S Minor Form</a>, as well as a <a href="https://ls.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/advcompletionoflnsminor.pdf">Major/Minor Overlap Check Form</a>, once they are enrolled in the final course(s) to complete the Music Minor. Be sure to obtain respective major advisor&#8217;s signature (unless waived&#8211;see below), and submit to the Department of Music main office in 104 Morrison (no appointment necessary).</p>
<p>Students must declare the Music Minor by the semester before they plan to graduate. If students plan to complete the final course(s) for the Music Minor in their last semester, they are required to submit the above-mentioned forms as soon as they enroll in the required Music courses, but no later than the last day of instruction in the preceding semester. For example, if you intend to graduate in Fall 2017 and need one Music elective for the minor, you must submit the completed and signed forms, and list the said elective as &#8220;enrolled,&#8221; as soon as you are enrolled in the course in October or November 2017.</p>
<p>Students in the following L&amp;S majors do not need to complete the &#8220;L&amp;S Major&#8221; portion of the Major/Minor Overlap Check Form or obtain their major advisor&#8217;s signature:</p>
<ul>
<li>Applied Math</li>
<li>Astrophysics</li>
<li>Economics</li>
<li>Integrative Biology</li>
<li>Legal Studies</li>
<li>Math</li>
<li>Molecular &amp; Cell Biology</li>
<li>Political Science</li>
<li>Social Welfare</li>
</ul>
<p>Declaration of the minor is confirmed when &#8220;Music UG&#8221; appears under Minors on student&#8217;s CalCentral profile. Completion of the minor will be reviewed and approved when all the listed courses receive a final grade. If certified, the completion of the minor will be noted in the &#8220;memorandum&#8221; section on your transcript. It will not appear on your diploma.</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-92 -->

										</div>

jQuery(document).ready(function($){
    $(".gallery img").each(function(){
        var alt = $(this).attr("alt");
        $(this).parent().attr("title",function(i,val){
            return val == alt ? "" : alt;
        });
    });
});
</script>

	<li id="menu-item-4915" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-4915"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/academic-programs/undergraduate-degree-program/placement-procedure-for-music-major-courses/">Placement Procedure</a>
	<ul class="sub-menu">

<article id="post-978" class="group post-container entry-content">

	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Music 140 Ensemble Courses</h1>
	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	<div class="entry-content-wrapper">
		<p><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-980" alt="baroque_pan_w" src="http://music.berkeley.edu/files/2014/03/baroque_pan_w.jpg" width="550" height="103" srcset="http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/baroque_pan_w.jpg 550w, http://music.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/baroque_pan_w-300x56.jpg 300w" sizes="(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px" /></p>
<p>Music 140 ensemble courses are part of the <a title="Performance Ensembles" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/news/performance-ensembles/">performance courses</a> requirement of the music major, and are also open to other students and members of the community by auditions. Ensembles are:</p>
<ul>
<li><a title="African Music Ensemble" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/african-music-ensemble/">African Music Ensemble</a>, music and dance of West Africa taught by a Ghanaian master drummer.</li>
<li><a title="University Gospel Chorus" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-gospel-chorus/">Gospel Chorus</a>, music of the African American gospel tradition with particular emphasis on contemporary performance techniques.</li>
<li><a title="Jazz &amp; Contemporary Improvised Music Ensemble (JCIME)" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/jazz-contemporary-improvised-music-ensemble-jcime/">Jazz &amp; Improvised Contemporary Music Ensemble</a>, an intermediate-advanced repertoire ensemble performing music that incorporates experimental practices in contemporary improvised music, encompassing several styles of music and a variety of approaches.</li>
<li><a title="Indonesian (Javanese) Gamelan" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/indonesian-javanese-gamelan/">Indonesian (Javanese) Gamelan</a>, music of the Indonesian island of Java, performed on the Music Department&#8217;s Gamelan Kyai Udan Mas. Students in the beginning class learn to play many of the instruments in the gamelan. Intermediate and advanced students may learn the more difficult instruments. Concert repertoire consists of traditional and contemporary gamelan compositions. Public performances may also feature Indonesian shadow play.</li>
<li><a title="University Baroque Ensemble" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-baroque-ensemble/">University Baroque Ensemble</a> features instrumental and vocal performance of music of the Baroque period (c.1580-c.1740) on historically appropriate instruments, using performance styles based on what is currently known of the performance practices of the country and period in which the pieces were composed. Whenever possible, the Ensemble performs directly from 17th- and 18th-century scores, learning to become familiar with the quite different kinds of musical notation used in earlier periods that often come from the extraordinarily rich Special Collections housed in Berkeley&#8217;s Jean Gray Hargrove Music Library.</li>
<li><a title="University Chorus" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-chorus/">University Chorus</a>: Critics have called the University Chorus &#8220;very impressive in sonority, quality of tone, and expressiveness.&#8221; (San Francisco Chronicle) and &#8220;flawless.&#8221; (San Francisco Classical Voice, March 2006). From Slavonic chant to standard choral-orchestral repertoire to contemporary music, this large chorus performs an exciting variety of literature.</li>
<li><a title="University Chamber Chorus" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-chamber-chorus/">University Chamber Chorus</a>. This grammy-winning ensemble has been praised by the New York Times, Washington Post, San Francisco Chronicle, and Opera News alike as &#8220;excellent,&#8221; &#8220;splendid,&#8221; &#8220;electric.&#8221; &#8220;The UC Chamber Chorus leaves no syllable unarticulated and no musical marvel unexplored&#8221; (San Francisco Examiner).</li>
<li><a title="UC Berkeley Symphony Orchestra" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/uc-berkeley-symphony-orchestra/">University Symphony</a>. Bold programming of both historical and contemporary repertory and high artistic standards have made this one of the country&#8217;s finest university orchestras; it is not only a pre-professional training orchestra, but a major performing ensemble in the Bay Area as well.</li>
<li><a title="University Wind Ensemble" href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-wind-ensemble/">University Wind Ensemble</a>, for the study and practice of traditional and contemporary wind band repertoire.</li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
	</div><!-- .entry-content-wrapper -->
</article><!-- #post-978 -->

										</div>
			</div><!-- #content -->



	</div><!-- #main -->

<li id="menu-item-4660" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-has-children menu-item-4660"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/">Performance Opportunities</a>
<ul class="sub-menu">
	<li id="menu-item-4662" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4662"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/audition-information/">Audition Information</a></li>

	<li id="menu-item-4665" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4665"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/indonesian-javanese-gamelan/">Indonesian (Javanese) Gamelan</a></li>

	<li id="menu-item-4667" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4667"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-baroque-ensemble/">University Baroque Ensemble</a></li>
	<li id="menu-item-4664" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-4664"><a href="http://music.berkeley.edu/performance-opportunities/university-chamber-chorus/">Chamber Chorus of the University of California</a></li>
